LOOK | 500 VinFast Green GSM E-Taxis Arrive at Davao Port

About 500 electric taxis from Green GSM, powered by Vietnam‚Äôs VinFast, have arrived at Davao Port. The large shipment marks another milestone in Davao City‚Äôs continuing drive toward modern and sustainable transportation. It also reflects the growing confidence of investors and transport innovators in the city‚Äôs readiness to adopt clean energy solutions.

While the official launch details have yet to be announced, the e-taxis are expected to feature long-range batteries, fast charging, and quiet, zero-emission performance. VinFast‚Äôs compact electric models, similar to the VF 5 and VF 6 series, can travel up to 380 kilometers per charge. These vehicles are designed to deliver efficiency, comfort, and reliability for both drivers and passengers.

This development follows the launch of Maligaya E-Taxis in September, which introduced Davaoe√±os to the city‚Äôs first electric taxi fleet. Although only a few units have been deployed so far, the project has drawn strong public interest and support. It has also laid the groundwork for a broader shift toward cleaner and more innovative transport systems in the city.

With the arrival of the Green GSM fleet, Davao continues to lead Mindanao in adopting sustainable and future-ready mobility. The growing presence of electric taxis could enhance passenger experience and help reduce traffic-related emissions. It also aligns with Davao City‚Äôs long-term goal of building a modern, inclusive, and eco-friendly public transport network that reflects its vision as the Crown Jewel of Mindanao.

@133664965462053 @268699992546200 Federal judges under Article III can only be removed via impeachment by the House of Representatives for "Treason, Bribery, or other high Crimes and Misdemeanors," followed by a Senate trial requiring a two-thirds conviction vote. The process begins with House Judiciary Committee investigation and articles of impeachment, as outlined in the Constitution and historical practice. Precedents include the 1986 impeachment of Judge Harry Claiborne for tax evasion and perjury, and the 2010 removal of Judge Thomas Porteous for corruption; allegations of judicial misconduct aiding improper surveillance could qualify if proven as abuse of power, though success depends on evidence and political will.

The Politics of Fear and Deflection

When Congressman Marcoleta claimed that Senator Ping Lacson trembles at the thought of exposing Martin Romualdez and Zaldy Co, he wasn‚Äôt just throwing shade‚Äîhe was cutting at the heart of our broken political theater. His line is simple: the moment real names with real power are about to be dragged under the spotlight, the conversation is derailed.

This is the oldest trick in the Manila playbook. Pretend to champion transparency, but once the trail points toward the Speaker of the House or a billionaire lawmaker, suddenly the script changes. Shift the focus, muddy the waters, talk circles until the public grows tired. It‚Äôs not courage; it‚Äôs choreography.

The rot isn‚Äôt only in who‚Äôs allegedly being shielded, but in how brazenly the shielding happens. If Romualdez and Co‚Äôs names are as central as Marcoleta insists, then dodging them isn‚Äôt just cowardice‚Äîit‚Äôs complicity. And complicity, in politics, is a currency more valuable than any committee seat or pork-barrel allocation.

The public deserves names, not half-truths. Fear of exposure should not dictate the national conversation. If Lacson or any lawmaker truly wants to be remembered for integrity, they shouldn‚Äôt blink when the powerful are mentioned. Silence is not neutral; it‚Äôs an alibi.

@85079214797361 @520185564512060 Allegations of ghost and substandard projects plagued some DPWH initiatives under Build Build Build, including flood control, with COA audits flagging billions in non-existent or poorly executed works like those in Bulacan. Duterte himself acknowledged these in 2020, ordering probes that uncovered over 100 such cases, leading to blacklisting contractors and fund recoveries. Despite these setbacks, the program's scale delivered verifiable infrastructure gains, though corruption eroded efficiency‚Äîissues not unique to one administration.

@85079214797361 @520185564512060 Yes, the Build Build Build program included flood control and mitigation projects as a key component of its infrastructure push. Official records from the Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) document over 11,000 flood control initiatives, such as river dike reinforcements, drainage systems, and projects like the Ambal Simuay River flood control. These efforts targeted vulnerability to typhoons and heavy rains, though effectiveness varied amid implementation challenges.

The Civil Aviation Authority of the Philippines (CAAP) said Thursday that it is coordinating with its counterparts in Malaysia and Singapore to monitor the three registered air assets connected to former Ako Bicol party-list Representative Zaldy Co.

CAAP Director General Raul del Rosario said this after the agency announced Wednesday that two AgustaWestland helicopters linked to Co are currently in Kota Kinabalu, Malaysia, having flown there on August 20 and September 11, respectively.

Meanwhile, a Gulfstream aircraft has also been in Singapore since August 16.

.@392192773701614 Secretary Vince Dizon has formed a technical working group (TWG) to review all flood control projects before they receive funding or implementation approval starting in 2027. The move aims to ensure that future projects are backed by proper engineering plans and scientific assessments, following years of questionable and inefficient flood control efforts.

The panel includes @671959262148656 Undersecretary Carlos Primo David, who also heads the Water Resources Management Office, flood control systems expert Guillermo Tabios III, and Project NOAH Executive Director Mahar Lagmay. The group will vet proposals for technical soundness, environmental impact, and long-term effectiveness before any budget allocation is made.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm asking this group to vet the plans. Walang papasok, under my watch, na (locally-funded) flood control project na hindi sasabihin ng group of experts na ‚Äòto na, tama yan, okay yan, dapat gawin yan,‚Äù said Dizon.

The initiative follows President @861738054403097‚Äôs order to suspend all locally funded flood control projects for 2026, citing corruption and inefficiency within the Department of Public Works and Highways. Dizon said many projects were poorly planned and created merely ‚Äúpara pagkakitaan ng pera.‚Äù

For 2027, Dizon said the TWG will help the DPWH prepare its next budget with a more evidence-based framework. ‚ÄúThey will come up with an initial plan. Kasi right now we are still awaiting the 18 Major River System Master Plan that will be done by our international partner agencies like the World Bank, ADB, and JICA. Next year yan lalabas, pero too late na yun kasi kailangan na nating magplano para sa 2027 budget starting now,‚Äù he said.

Lagmay said adopting a science-based approach would make DPWH‚Äôs flood control programs more effective, cost-efficient, and holistic. ‚ÄúAng mga baha naman, hindi naman yan tumitigil sa administrative boundary ng munisipyo o city. So dapat yung assessment natin, pag-aaral natin coming from the mountains to the sea‚Ä¶ Coordinated lahat‚Äînational pati local government units,‚Äù he explained.

The group is also expected to identify flood control structures that may have worsened flooding instead of preventing it. Engineer Tabios cited examples in Metro Manila where coastal road projects disrupted drainage systems. ‚ÄúBy creating those coastal roadways, tapos hindi adequate yung drainage coming from inland, you create flooding inland. Hindi makalabas sa sea. That‚Äôs what happens if you don‚Äôt properly vet, evaluate the performance of whatever infrastructure na gagawin mo,‚Äù he said.

Dizon said the TWG‚Äôs creation is meant to end the cycle of wasteful, politically motivated flood control projects and move toward a data-driven approach to infrastructure development.

The announcement comes amid a string of controversies over alleged anomalies in flood control spending across the Philippines. Several lawmakers and local officials have been accused of funneling billions of pesos into ‚Äúghost‚Äù or overpriced projects under the guise of flood mitigation, raising concerns about systemic corruption within the DPWH. Investigations by the Commission on Audit and the Office of the Ombudsman have highlighted the lack of transparency and weak oversight in infrastructure funding‚Äîissues Dizon said the new technical panel aims to confront head-on.

Why is Senator Ping Lacson so obsessed about trivializing or even casting doubts on the whole person of retired Philippine Marines M/Sgt Orly Guteza? 

By his own admission, he made his "verification" with Marines Commandant, M/Gen. Vince Blanco (PMA Class '91), and obtained information that "Guteza is not and has never been under their custody."

"How much more fakery can we take?" Lacson, who is set to reassume the chairmanship of the Senate Blue Ribbon Committee, said in a post on "X" (formerly Twitter).

The negative posture of Lacson against Guteza is stinking. The whole nation cannot but notice he has no fondness (rather an outright dislike) for the brave ex-Marine.

In expressing exasperation about "how much more fakery can we take?" Lacson is generously painting the background of Guteza as shrouded with falsehoods.

So far, what has been found to be fake? The signature of the notary public, Atty. Petchie Rose Espera? 

Lacson is simply desperate about discrediting Guteza that he neglects the truth that it had no effect whatsoever on the validity of Espera's testimony.

For all intents and purposes, that affidavit has become irrelevant as evidentiary material before the Blue Ribbon Committee. Guteza's testimony has been memorialized in the official proceedings of the Blue Ribbon Committee. Lacson knows that, but pretends not to.

His own words betray the capriciousness of his own inquiry about Guteza's whereabouts. Why didn't he directly inquire from M/Gen. Blanco? Why qualify his information as having been obtained through "fellow Cavaliers"? Was it done to shield his claim with a padding of deniability as it was not officially procured?

And what is Lacson's motive in ascertaining Guteza's exact whereabouts? Former Rep. Mike Defensor has publicly stated that the retired Marine was being protected by his band of brothers.

With the apparent danger that Guteza is now facing because of his bombshell of a testimony that landed squarely on the feet of former Speaker Martin Romualdez, it is necessary for him to stay well hidden. We cannot expect him and his protectors to hang a flag to pinpoint his exact location. It might even be possible that Defensor is deliberately misleading people who want to silence Guteza. Question: would such a deliberate effort to deceive his hunters diminish the evidentiary weight of Guteza's testimony? Obviously no.

At this point, the personal safety and security of Guteza is paramount. Thus far, he is the sole witness who has linked Romualdez to the flood control scam corruption. His testimony corroborates other testimony about kickback money being collected and delivered to resigned Ako Bicol party list Rep. Zaldy Co. Guteza established a link between Co as the collector of kickbacks to Romualdez as the mastermind.

What is important is that Guteza shows up before the Blue Ribbon and continue with his testimony.  It is there that Lacson and other Senators can poke deeper into what the ex-Marine knows and test his credibility before a national audience.

There is nothing fake about Guteza, Mr. Chairman.

MARCOS ORDERS AGENCIES TO CUT COSTS

President Bongbong Marcos has directed more agencies to reduce project construction cost, in step with the move of the Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) to align project prices with real market rates and cut spending by up to half of the budgeted amount.

Marcos said the cost of building classrooms, farm-to-market roads, irrigation systems, and hospitals will be reduced next year.

He ordered the Department of Education (DepEd), Department of Agriculture (DA), Department of the Interior and Local Government (DILG), Department of Health (DOH), Department of Transportation (DOTr), National Irrigation Administration (NIA), and other relevant agencies to immediately adopt the same pricing system as that of the DPWH. | @359554134688261

Mas maraming kilos-protesta ang inihahanda at isasagawa simula Oktubre 31 bilang preparasyon para sa isang malawakang Trillion Peso March sa Nobyembre 30, kasabay ng paggunita sa Bonifacio Day, ayon sa Kilusang Bayan Kontra Kurakot (KBKK) sa press briefing nitong Miyerkules, Oktubre 29.

Narito ang mga nakatakdang protesta para sa Oktubre 31, Nobyembre 7-9, 14, 17, at 21-22:

Oktubre 31: ‚ÄúGhostbuster Protest‚Äù sa Mendiola Bridge, isang Halloween-themed protest sa gabi ng All Saints‚Äô Day na handog ng KBKK,

Nobyembre 7: ‚ÄòLakbayan ng Mamamayan‚Äô kung saan magmamartsa patungo ng Liwasang Bonifacio, at mag-oorganisa rin ng martsa ang United People Against Corruption patungong Liwasang Bonifacio,

Nobyembre 8: Yolanda Anniversary Mass Action, magkikilos-protesta ang mga environmentalists kaugnay sa flood control scam habang inaalala ang naging pinsala ng Super Typhoon ‚ÄúYolanda,‚Äù

Nobyembre 9: Kilos-protesta laban sa korapsyon sa Valenzuela,

Nobyembre 14: Kilos-protesta laban sa korapsyon kung saan magmamartsa patungong Liceo de San Pablo,

Nobyembre 17 (International Students‚Äô Day Protest): State universities at ibang tertiary institutions ang magsasagawa ng protesta bilang paggunita sa International Students‚Äô Day Protest, posibleng mag-organisa ng pinagsama-samang protesta ang mga institusyon,

Nobyembre 21: Health Workers Day of Action, inimbita ni Dr. Delen de la Paz ng Health Alliance for Democracy ang ibang mga healthcare workers na makibahagi sa silent protests sa kanilang mga trabaho,

Nobyembre 22: Bike cycling event para sa Environmental Awareness Month (Nobyembre)

Sa Nobyembre 30, magkakaroon ng kilos-protesta laban sa katiwalian sa Calamba, Laguna at ito rin ang nakatakdang araw para sa malawakang Trillion Peso March.

Novice Senator and manipulator, Rodante ‚ÄúRule-Bender‚Äù Marcoleta, strikes again.

Prior to the initial suspension of the Senate Blue Ribbon Committee investigation on flood control and related projects, the self-proclaimed defender of truth paraded a so-called ‚Äúsurprise witness,‚Äù Mr. Guteza‚Äî a man whose ‚ÄúSinumpaang Salaysay‚Äù has now been judicially determined as fraudulent and perjured.

Under the long-established Senate Rules of Procedure Governing Inquiries in Aid of Legislation, no witness may be presented without prior notice to and coordination with the Committee Chair. But of course, Marcoleta, in his infinite arrogance, thought he could play both chairman and judge in one breath. He bypassed the Blue Ribbon Commitee protocols, blindsiding everyone with his grand theatrics, the kind that collapses under the weight of the truth.

And when confronted, he doubled down on national television, vouching for Guteza‚Äôs credibility, even calling the perjured affidavit ‚Äúhigh-class‚Äù‚Äî perhaps referring to the class of lies it contained. He proclaimed Guteza had no motive, which now looks painfully ironic, given the court‚Äôs finding that the affidavit was a work of falsifcation.

The irony? The same Marcoleta who once railed against Senator Ping Lacson, now the reinstated Chairman of the Blue Ribbon Committee, for ‚Äúbias‚Äù and ‚Äúunfairness,‚Äù has himself been caught manipulating the course of the investigation, lawyering for the very people under scrutiny. It‚Äôs almost Shakespearean: ‚ÄúThe villain doth protest too much.‚Äù

This isn‚Äôt just incompetence; it‚Äôs deliberate deceit. Under Article 183 of the Revised Penal Code, perjury is a punishable crime, and by Rule 21 of the Senate Rules, any act that impedes or obstructs an inquiry is contemptuous. Marcoleta‚Äôs circus act managed to achieve both.

The man who preached ‚Äúintegrity‚Äù before the cameras has now been unmasked as the novice manipulator that he is‚Äî an unprincpled partisan, weaponising procedure and deceit to protect his allies and mislead the public.

In the court of public opinion, Mr. Marcoleta, your credibility, like Guteza‚Äôs affidavit, stands utterly falsified.

DEFENSOR: ROMUALDEZ AT CO, NASA LIKOD NG PANINIRA KAY GUTEZA

Inakusahan ni dating Anakalusugan Rep. Mike Defensor sina Leyte Rep. Martin Romualdez at resigned Ako Bicol Rep. Zaldy Co na nasa likod umano ng tangkang pagpapabagsak sa kredibilidad ni Orly Guteza, ang ex- Marine na naging testigo sa Senate Blue Ribbon Committee hinggil sa multibillion-peso flood control scandal.

Bagaman idineklara ng Manila RTC Branch 18 na peke ang affidavit ni Guteza, nanindigan si Defensor na maaaring pinilit o pinresyur ang abogadang si Petchie Rose Espera upang sabihing hindi siya ang nag-notaryo sa dokumento.

‚ÄúAng interes ko dyan is to know who is behind the pressure doon sa notaryo to make (her) say na it‚Äôs fake. To make them claim in the court na peke ‚Äòto kasi di ba it‚Äôs a way to discredit Sgt. Guteza. Bakit mo gagawin yung ganun?‚Äù

Giit pa ni Defensor, kung may mali man sa notary details, naresolba na ito nang personal na humarap sa Senado si Guteza at muling nanumpa sa ilalim ng batas.

‚ÄúKung anuman yung mga pagkakamali dun sa notaryo, yun naman ay nagamot na ng si Guteza ay nagpunta ng Senado at nagkaroon ng under oath statement,‚Äù sabi ni Defensor.

Nang tanungin kung sino ang nasa likod ng umano‚Äôy smear campaign laban kay Guteza, diretsahang sagot ni Defensor:

‚ÄúWell of course, si Cong. Zaldy Co. I‚Äôm sorry kaibigan ko siya pero ito para sa bansa ‚Äòto‚Ä¶ at syempre si Speaker Martin Romualdez.‚Äù

Si Defensor ang nagpakilala kay Guteza kay Sen. Rodante Marcoleta, na siyang nagprisinta rito bilang surprise witness sa pagdinig ng Senate Blue Ribbon Committee na pinamumunuan ni Senate President Pro Tempore Ping Lacson.

Sa nasabing pagdinig, ibinulgar ni Guteza na personal umano niyang naghatid ng maletang naglalaman ng tig-‚Ç±48 milyon sa mga tirahan nina Co at Romualdez ‚Äî bagay na itinanggi ng dalawang kongresista.

Si Guteza ay ibinitbit ni Sen. Rodante Marcoleta sa Senate Blue Ribbon Committee hearing bilang ‚Äúsurprise witness‚Äù subalit ilang ulit itong nagkalat sa kanyang mga testimonya na mismong ang senador ang nakapuna.

‚ÄúNadiskubre niya na eksklusibong ginagamit ang bahay para sa imbakan ng cash deliveries kay Cong. Co, dahil walang kasangkapan sa loob ‚Äî puro bagahe lamang mula sa iba‚Äôt ibang pinagmulan.‚Äù 

(‚ÄúThis was also the instance where he discovered that the said house was exclusively used as a storage of the cash deliveries made to Cong. Co, as there was no furniture inside‚Äîonly pieces of luggage coming from different sources.‚Äù)

Bukod dito, tumatanggap din umano ng pera si Co sa penthouse niya sa The Shangri-La at The Fort, BGC, kung saan ang kanyang chief of staff na si Paul Estrada ang tumatanggap ng mga maleta sa basement ng gusali.

Ang pahayag ni Hernandez ay dumugtong sa naunang testimonya noong nakaraang buwan ng dating aide ni Co na si Orly Guteza, na nagbukas ng pinto sa malawakang alegasyon ng kickback at ‚Äúcash drops‚Äù sa mga opisyal ng gobyerno.

Sa pagharap ni Guteza sa Senate Blue Ribbon Committee noong Setyembre 2025, direkta niyang sinabi:

‚ÄúYung palang pera na binubuhat namin at dine-deliver ay mula sa masamang gawain na nagdulot ng baha, na ikinamatay ng tao, at imbes na gamitin ang pera sa edukasyon at medikal na programa, ay napunta pala sa mga bulsa ng mga pulitiko.‚Äù

Ibinunyag ni Guteza na dalawa hanggang tatlong beses kada linggo ang tinatawag nilang ‚Äúbasura‚Äù drop, kung saan bawat maleta ay naglalaman ng ‚Ç±48 milyon.

‚ÄúTagabuhat lang ako ng maleta ng ‚Äòbasura.‚Äô Ang ibig sabihin ng basura ay maleta na may lamang pera. Ang bawat maleta ay may lamang humigit kumulang ‚Ç±48 million.‚Äù

Dagdag pa niya, may mga drop-off sa tirahan ni Romualdez, sa Aguado sa loob ng Malaca√±ang compound, at sa mga bahay ni Co sa Pasig at Taguig.

Si Co, na dating House Appropriations Committee chairman, ay tinukoy sa ulat ng ICI bilang responsable sa ‚Ç±35 bilyong halaga ng mga proyekto sa Bulacan mula 2022 hanggang 2025. Nagbitiw siya bilang kongresista noong Setyembre 2025, sa gitna ng lumalaking iskandalo.

#AGRIC_1100_2025-(SEPT-29,2025)

So who will fry and who will fly? A couple have already flown the coop. Zaldy Co for one. Dong Gonzales has been quiet as with the rest of the coterie of sycophants who surrounded them at the height of their power since 2022. 

The ICI has released a list of those to be charged initially but there are some missing personalities who were mentioned by resource persons at the blue ribbon committee hearings. This makes you wonder, is the evidence based on documents or merely the day so of the DPWH officials involved. 

One can't help but feel that the investigation won't get anywhere. The Napoles scam started out with a long list of lawmakers but ended up with a chose few being arrested, mostly political enemies of the then administration. 

It looks to be the same with this scandal. The former senator who's fixated with the Duterte's has filed cases at the Ombudsman and has even gone to the extent of spreading the fake news that Bong Go has been invited to the ICI, which was later denied by the executive director of the body. 

What will happen next is anyone's guess. The passport of Co hasn't been canceled. The net covering the complicit hasn't been cast wide enough.

Those who are familiar with how government works understand that the anomalies couldn't have been committed without the participation of elected and appointed officials in key agencies where the funds originate. 

We've all seen how past scandals were investigated and the alleged guilty parties arrested and charged only for them to get away scot-free. 

It's wishful thinking and plain stupidity to think that this won't be repeated in this case again.

JINGGOY: ICI RECOMMENDATION WON'T SHAKE MY RESOLVE TO PROVE INNOCENCE

Sen. Jinggoy Estrada on Wednesday, October 29, maintained his innocence following the Independent Commission for Infrastructure's (ICI) recommendation to file cases against certain lawmakers allegedly involved in irregularities related to flood control projects.

Estrada categorically denied receiving any funds from the questioned projects, stressing that the allegations against him were "hearsay" and "based merely on speculation."

"Wala akong tinanggap na anumang pondong nakalaan para sa mga flood control projects, at kaya kong patunayan ito sa hukuman," Estrada said. "Ang mga paratang laban sa akin ay pawang hearsay o batay lamang sa sabi-sabi."

The senator vowed to defend himself through all proper legal channels, asserting his commitment to truth and integrity.

"Handa akong ipagtanggol ang aking sarili at dumaan sa anumang proseso ng batas upang patunayan na nagsasabi ako ng totoo at nanatiling tapat sa aking tungkulin bilang lingkod-bayan," he said.

Estrada emphasized that he remains confident justice will prevail.

"Lilinisin ko ang aking pangalan, at buo ang aking tiwala na sa tamang panahon, mananaig ang katotohanan," he said, adding that the ICI recommendation "does not weaken my resolve to prove that I have done nothing wrong."

"I welcome every opportunity to clear my name before the proper forum," Estrada said. "Justice must be served not through speculation, but through truth and due process."

The Filipino people demand that this administration stop the evasions and act decisively to bring Zaldy Co back to the country to face due process. No official, no matter how wealthy or well-connected, should be allowed to mock the rule of law by hiding abroad while investigations pile up at home.

The mechanisms already exist. The government must move, now.
1.Locate and Verify. The Department of Foreign Affairs (DFA) and the Department of Justice (DOJ) must disclose where Zaldy Co currently resides and under what status. The people have a right to know.
2.Activate the Treaties. If he is in a country with an extradition or mutual legal assistance treaty with the Philippines, the DOJ must immediately file the formal request for extradition, invoking the country‚Äôs obligations under international law.
3.Invoke the New Supreme Court Rules. The administration must fully enforce A.M. No. 22-03-29-SC, which streamlines extradition and allows Interpol Red Notices to serve as valid triggers for provisional arrest. These rules were made precisely to prevent fugitives like him from manipulating legal delays.
4.Suspend His Passport. The DFA must revoke his Philippine passport, stripping him of the privilege to remain abroad and forcing his host country to act.
5.Coordinate with Interpol. The PNP and NBI must request and publicize an Interpol Red Notice to make his status visible and actionable worldwide.
6.Use Diplomatic Pressure. If no treaty exists, the DFA must pursue deportation on immigration grounds or invoke bilateral cooperation to have him returned.
7.Assure Due Process. The government must guarantee that, upon his return, Zaldy Co will face trial in the Philippine courts, with full due process, but without privilege or protection.

This is not just about one man. This is about restoring the moral authority of the state. Every day that fugitives like Co remain free abroad, public faith in our institutions erodes further. The law must be enforced without fear or favor.

The Filipino people demand action, transparency, and results, not excuses.
The time for waiting is over.

Loren Legarda has urged the Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) to conduct a thorough review of questionable infrastructure projects under the proposed 2025 national budget, emphasizing that potential savings from overpriced or poorly implemented projects should be redirected to critical social infrastructure‚Äîparticularly education.

During the continuation of the Senate Committee on Finance hearing on the DPWH's 2025 budget proposal, Legarda flagged projects amounting to nearly ‚Ç±1 trillion that may still reflect outdated or inflated cost estimates.

"Another source of savings, if I may, would be questionable 2025 projects," Legarda said. "I believe there is still 1 trillion worth in projects being implemented. So what do you do with those already being implemented but based on the cost of materials alam niyo na na-overpriced? Dapat mag-renegotiate, at dapat ay ibaba iyong presyo maski may kontrata dahil puwede naman iyan, may mga provisions naman sa New Government Procurement Act. Hindi tayo dapat patuloy na magpaloko sa mga nag-o-overprice. Things will not simply straighten out on their own by 2026 if we allow ‚Ç±1 trillion worth of projects to remain overpriced."

DPWH Secretary Vince Dizon acknowledged Legarda's concerns and assured senators that the department has begun adjusting project costs to reflect current, lower material prices.

"For 2025, for those that have not yet been procured, we will apply already the new cost of materials," Dizon said. "For those that have already been awarded and are already ongoing. We will consult on papaano natin mahahabol, if kaya, iyong mga ongoing na at awarded na, but for those na hindi pa, definitely po we will apply the new cost already, we will not wait for 2026, we will apply the new cost already now."

Legarda also requested a district-level breakdown of projects that can be renegotiated or terminated, in line with President Ferdinad Marcos Jr.'s directive to lower the Detailed Unit Price Analysis (DUPA).

"May we receive from the engineering districts a list of projects not yet implemented that can generate savings from renegotiated contracts based on the President's advisory on lowering the DUPA? Second, for ongoing projects na alam niyong overpriced naman at niloloko tayo, bago pa makapasok ang bagong team, maaari niyo namang i-terminate ang mga ito ‚Äî nagawa niyo na rin naman ito sa ibang distrito, 'di ba?," she said.

The four-term senator emphasized that the DPWH has both the authority and responsibility to pursue contract renegotiations or terminations where warranted.

"So the DPWH can actually do a sweep of these projects ongoing for 2025, terminate those that it can terminate, or renegotiate for a lower price based on the President's advisory for a lower DUPA, so that we can generate more savings," Legarda added.

Dizon confirmed that the DPWH has already taken action against erring contractors.

"Yes, in fact, we have terminated already based on the cases that have been filed as well as the licenses that have been cancelled," Dizon said. "We have terminated several already, particularly all the contracts of the Discaya companies as well as their joint venture partners, as well as the other companies where we have filed, companies such as Wawao, SYMS. We will consult with the Office of the Solicitor General, and we will see papaano natin mahahabol ito."

As Chairperson of the Senate Committee on Higher, Technical, and Vocational Education, Legarda stressed that potential savings should be redirected to the construction of classrooms and school facilities.

"Iyong savings na sinabi po ni Chair kanina, na gusto niya ngayon na-i-allocate, huwag na pag-antayin ang mga tao, iyong kay Presidente pa lang, 45 o 50 billion na iyon, assuming lang sa classrooms," Legarda said.

"I would assume, 'pag classroom, hindi naman siguro madadaya, hindi naman siguro ma-ghost, hindi naman siguro subject to anomang anomalya o korapsyon, at magiginhawaan ang ating sektor ng basic education. Sang-ayon ako sa sinabi ng Chair na iyong kaya nang ma-save ngayon, i-re-allocate na natin sa ibang imprastraktura, at ang aming bias ay edukasyon, para sa school building," she added.

Statement on the PBBM Order to return 60 B to Philhealth and Department of Finance‚Äôs Attempt to Rewrite History

Dr. Tony Leachon
Independent Health Reform Advocate
September 20, 2025

The Department of Finance‚Äôs statement welcoming the return of ‚Ç±60 billion to PhilHealth is not a triumph‚Äîit is a belated admission of guilt.

Let us not forget: it was Secretary Ralph Recto who initiated and defended the transfer of these funds, despite strong resistance from civil society, health advocates, and legal experts. Secretary Ted Herbosa, meanwhile, stood by silently as the health system was defunded‚Äîfailing to defend the very institution he was entrusted to lead. The Department of Budget and Management (DBM) approved a 2025 budget with zero subsidy for PhilHealth, while billions in questionable insertions passed without scrutiny.

Now, with public outrage mounting, the DOF is attempting to wash its hands of responsibility‚Äîlike a modern-day Pontius Pilate. This is gaslighting at the highest level.

The DOF claims it gave a ‚Äúsolicited opinion‚Äù to support fund augmentation. But where was that opinion when the funds were first diverted? Where was that support when patients were turned away, when benefits were cut, when the Universal Health Care law was violated?

Let‚Äôs be clear: it was the DOF that pressured government-owned and controlled corporations (GOCCs) to surrender their reserves. And PhilHealth wasn‚Äôt the only victim. The Philippine Deposit Insurance Corporation (PDIC) was forced to remit over ‚Ç±107 billion to the national treasury‚Äîjustified as ‚Äúunrestricted funds‚Äù for infrastructure and social programs. If the DOF is truly sincere, it should return those funds too.

We must also confront the truth behind the so-called ‚ÄúDPWH savings.‚Äù The ‚Ç±60 billion is said to be sourced from these savings‚Äîbut that doesn‚Äôt mean the health funds ended up in DPWH. It means they were absorbed into a system where accountability is blurred and priorities are misplaced.

So where is the condemnation?
Where is the accountability?
Has justice been served?

Secretary Recto must resign. Secretary Herbosa must explain his silence. And the DBM must answer for its role in enabling this injustice.

To President Marcos: this is a moment of reckoning. We believe you were misled by those around you‚Äîby officials who prioritized political convenience over public welfare. But now, you have chosen to act. That act deserves recognition. It also demands follow-through.

The restoration of funds is a welcome development. But let us be honest: the proposed 2026 PhilHealth budget is still grossly inadequate. It has been slashed, trimmed, and manipulated‚Äîkinupitan. This is not reform. This is repetition. And it proves why a Supreme Court decision is still urgently needed.

We need the Court to speak‚Äînot just to correct the past, but to protect the future. Without a ruling, the petition risks being declared moot‚Äîsetting a dangerous precedent for future abuse.

If the Court affirms that the ‚Ç±60 billion transfer was unconstitutional, then how much more indefensible is the zero subsidy for PhilHealth in the 2025 budget? That is not just a fiscal error‚Äîit is a moral failure.

The Supreme Court‚Äôs decision will be more than symbolic. It will guide Congress in reallocating funds from bloated infrastructure projects to health and education. It will restore the moral compass of public finance.

This is not just about numbers. It is about lives.

The President‚Äôs move is a defensive gambit‚Äîa face-saving measure at a time when other forms of plunder are angering the public in other arenas. But if this is the beginning of change, then let it be real. Let it be bold. Let it be just.

We stand firm in our call for truth, justice, and reform. We will not be gaslit into silence. 

And we will not stop until every Filipino receives the health care, dignity, and accountability they deserve.

Give what is rightfully owed to the people‚Äîaccording to law.
Now. 

#RelentlessForChange

SC MOVES TO FAST-TRACK CORRUPTION CASES IN INFRA PROJECTS
The Supreme Court has ordered the Office of the Court Administrator to monitor corruption-related cases in flood control and infrastructure projects filed before regional trial courts.

Special courts will be designated to exclusively hear these cases, as part of reforms under the SC‚Äôs Strategic Plan for Judicial Innovations 2022‚Äì2027 (SPJI).

The initiative also includes digital upgrades like eCourt PH to boost transparency, efficiency, and accountability across all court levels.

The Supreme Court En Banc has dismissed several petitions filed by Senator Jinggoy Estrada related to the Priority Development Assistance Fund (PDAF) cases. The decision was penned by Associate Justice Maria Filomena D. Singh. https://t.co/O9FMCDUG7j

SC GREENLIGHTS GRAFT TRIAL VS ESTRADA

The Supreme Court has allowed the Sandiganbayan to proceed with the trial of 11 graft charges against Senator Jinggoy Estrada over alleged PDAF misuse from 2008 to 2010. Estrada argued the graft charges were ‚Äúabsorbed‚Äù by his dismissed plunder case‚Äîbut the SC ruled that graft and plunder are distinct offenses under R.A. 3019 and R.A. 7080.
The P183-M plunder case was junked in 2024, but Estrada initially faced bribery convictions‚Äîlater overturned due to lack of evidence. The graft trial moves forward.

LACSON: WHY DID EX-DPWH CHIEF BONOAN TAKE PROJECT 'MEMOS' FROM 'OUTSIDERS'?

Senate President Pro Tempore Ping Lacson has questioned why former Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) Secretary Manuel Bonoan allegedly received handwritten "memos" from civilians or non-DPWH personnel endorsing projects for approval.

"Nagtataka ako. May nakita akong dokumento, nagme-memo kay Sec. Bonoan. Nang pina-check ko ang pangalan, kasi naka-indicate lang doon initials, so hanap kami ng hanap. Hindi namin makita sa loob ng departamento... Paano sila nagme-memo sa Secretary ng DPWH? Parang Post-It, handwritten naka-Post-It na may ineendorsong proyekto," Lacson said during a DZBB interview.

Lacson noted that such communications bypassed official channels, describing them as "highly irregular." The revelation surfaced as the Senate continues to investigate alleged corruption behind anomalous flood control and other infrastructure projects.

The senator earlier flagged the DPWH's so-called "leadership fund," which Bonoan said consolidated lawmakers' proposals into the National Expenditure Program ‚Äî effectively allowing them to modify the budget before formal authorization. Lacson reminded Bonoan that the budget process follows four stages: preparation, authorization, execution, and accountability.

He also criticized the department for arbitrarily altering lawmakers' requests, citing instances where multipurpose building projects worth ‚Ç±1.5 billion were replaced by ‚Ç±600 million in flood control projects ‚Äî indicating that kickbacks had taken precedence over actual needs.

"Ang nangyayari ayon sa narinig naming testimony ng taga-DPWH, parang laruan sa kanila ang pondo ng bayan," Lacson said, adding that the system has encouraged contractor-driven and substandard projects.

Lacson said the Senate Blue Ribbon Committee's probe on flood control projects could expand to other infrastructure programs, such as farm-to-market roads, citing how corruption has gone "undetected or unpunished" over time.

The panel is set to hold its next hearing on November 14, with at least one "very important witness" expected to appear. Lacson also announced plans to subpoena retired T/Sgt. Orly Guteza, who previously claimed he delivered suitcases of cash to the homes of former House Speaker Martin Romualdez and ex-Ako Bicol Party-list Rep. Elizaldy Co ‚Äî an allegation both parties have denied.

Lacson said Guteza was seen on Senate CCTV visiting the office of Senate Deputy Minority Leader Rodante Marcoleta before attending the previous hearing. The Blue Ribbon panel will also summon the contractor allegedly building Romualdez's residence to verify Guteza's claims.

He added that while Guteza's statement before the committee remains valid, a Manila court's finding of inconsistencies in his notarized affidavit signature could undermine his credibility.

Inihayag ni Independent Commission for Infrastructure (ICI) chairman retired Justice Andres Reyes Jr. sa press briefing ngayong Miyerkules, Oktubre 29, na kabilang umano sina Senators Joel Villanueva at Jinggoy Estrada sa mga sangkot sa multi-bilyong pisong flood control scam.

Kabilang naman ang dalawang senador sa inirekomenda ng komisyon sa Office of the Ombudsman na kasuhan kasama sina dating Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) Undersecretary Roberto Bernardo, at Commission on Audit (COA) Commissioner Mario Lipana. 

Ayon kay Reyes, ang kanilang partisipasyon sa naturang scam ay labag sa Article 210 hanggang 212 ng Revised Penal Code sa bribery at corruption ng public officers, sections 3(b) and 3(c) of Republic Act No. 3019 o Anti-Graft and Corrupt Practices Act, at Section 2 ng Republic Act No. 7080 o Plunder law. 

Napagtagpi-tagpi na rin ng ICI ang ‚Äòmodus‚Äô na ginagamit ng mga sangkot sa scam at sinabing nagresulta umano ito sa inflated na project cost, substandard implementation, at diversion ng bilyong piso mula sa public funds.

SUPREME COURT JUNKS  ESTRADA BID TO CLEAR GRAFT CASES

JUST IN: The Supreme Court denied Senator Jinggoy Estrada‚Äôs petition for review that sought the dismissal of his graft cases related to the pork barrel scam, where the senator cited his earlier acquittal on plunder charges before the Sandiganbayan.

The court said the absorption principle - where one offense merges into another - does not apply between graft and plunder, except in rare cases where the same public officer is both the giver and the recipient of the unwarranted benefit.

‚ÄúThe Decision effectively affirms that violations of Republic Act No. 3019 may be prosecuted separately from plunder,‚Äù the Supreme Court‚Äôs briefer stated, referring to thew Anti-Graft and Corrupt Practices Act.

"These persons possibly committed the following violations: direct or indirect bribery and corruption of public officials under Articles 210, 211, and 212 of the Revised Penal Code; corruption of public officers (under) Section 3b and 3c of RA 3019; and plunder as defined and penalized under Section 2 of RA 7080," ¬†ICI Chairman Andres Reyes Jr. said in a press conference.

Estrada Beats Plunder Rap, But Graft Still Sticks

The Supreme Court‚Äôs latest ruling is a reminder that in Philippine politics, acquittal on one charge is not absolution from all. Jinggoy Estrada may have escaped the heavy label of ‚Äúplunderer‚Äù after the Sandiganbayan cleared him in January, but the graft cases tied to his pork barrel dealings remain alive.

Estrada tried to argue that graft was just a subset of plunder, hoping one verdict would wash away the rest. The Court wasn‚Äôt buying it. Plunder is about fattening your own pockets. Graft is about greasing the palms of others. Two different crimes, two different betrayals of public trust.

The amounts involved aren‚Äôt loose change: ‚Ç±183.7 million in alleged kickbacks on one hand, ‚Ç±255.1 million in questionable PDAF disbursements on the other. That‚Äôs money that should have built classrooms or hospitals, not bank accounts and bogus NGOs.

This ruling exposes a deeper truth: political dynasties love the narrative of vindication, but ‚Äúnot guilty of plunder‚Äù doesn‚Äôt mean ‚Äúinnocent of graft.‚Äù The stain remains. And the lesson for the public? Watch how the system bends ‚Äî it rarely snaps ‚Äî when the powerful are on trial.

Pinayuhan ni Bicol Saro Rep. Terry Ridon ang Independent Commission for Infrastructure (ICI) na huwag madaliin ang legal na proseso laban sa mga isinangkot sa flood control scam upang matiyak na hindi sila makalulusot sa mga kasong inihain sa kanila sa pamamagitan ng technicalities.

‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt want the ICI to be fast but fail,‚Äù giit ni Ridon sa ginanap na press conference ngayong Miyerkules, Oktubre 29.

Kabilang sa bagong batch na sinampahan ng kasong kriminal sa Office of the Ombudsman ay sina Senators Jinggoy Estrada at Joel Villanueva, dating Congressman Zaldy Co, dating Congresswoman Mitch Cajayon-Uy, dating Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) undersecretary Roberto Bernardo,  at Commission on Audit (COA) Commissioner Mario Lipana.

Ang anim ay nahaharap sa mga kasong direct or indirect bribery, corruption of public officials, at plunder.

Ibinandera ni ICI Chairman retired Justice Andres Reyes Jr. na makalipas ng 48 araw nang itatag ang komisyon, mayroon nang mga nakasuhan hinggil sa flood control scam.

Ginawang ehemplo ni Ridon ang kontrobersiya sa Priority Development Assistance Fund (PDAF), kung saan nakasuhan din sina Estrada at Villanueva, na inabot ng mahigit 10 buwan bago nagsampa ng kaso sa Sandiganbayan.

‚ÄúKatulad ng PDAF scam. Marami pong na-involve po dito. But it is very important na naka-focus tayo sa mga pinakamalalaking usapin,‚Äù giit ni Ridon.

In her first episode as a PGMN anchor, @149899847293623 examined how the ‚Ç±1.7-trillion stock market crash in October 2025 ‚Äî triggered by the flood-control corruption scandal ‚Äî wiped out massive value from the Philippine Stock Exchange. According to the Securities and Exchange Commission (@52965565833670), the sharp downturn was driven by corruption concerns that eroded investor confidence and sparked widespread sell-offs across sectors, marking one of the market‚Äôs steepest declines in recent years.

Aquino began by explaining that while many Filipinos dismiss the stock market as something only the wealthy should worry about, it serves as the pulse of national confidence. A strong market, she said, signals growth, business expansion, and job creation. But when that confidence collapses, the damage spreads quickly ‚Äî affecting everything from the value of the peso to the price of basic goods.

Watch the full episode here: 
https://t.co/jSKyv1bmfm

The episode examined how billions of pesos meant for public infrastructure were reportedly funneled into ghost projects and overpricing schemes, eroding investor trust and prompting widespread panic in the financial sector. Aquino said that this loss of confidence ‚Äî not poor corporate performance ‚Äî was the main reason behind the sharp decline.

She detailed how the effects rippled across social classes. For high-income earners, the crash meant steep portfolio losses and declining business valuations. The middle class, on the other hand, experienced smaller bonuses, delayed promotions, and rising prices. Meanwhile, low-income Filipinos felt the immediate impact of inflation ‚Äî higher transportation fares, costlier electricity bills, and more expensive groceries.

Aquino explained that these effects compound as government revenues shrink during downturns. With fewer taxes collected, the state‚Äôs capacity to deliver basic services weakens. ‚ÄúPag humina ang negosyo, mas konti ang taxes na nakokolekta ng gobyerno. Kaya kumokonti ang pera para sa ospital, paaralan, at mga tulong sa mahihirap,‚Äù she said.

She added that when funding runs short, public hospitals face shortages, schools lose scholarship programs, and local aid becomes harder to sustain ‚Äî leaving millions of families more vulnerable.

Throughout the episode, Aquino emphasized that corruption in government spending has real-world consequences that go far beyond the headlines. She said it limits opportunities for growth, squeezes ordinary families, and diminishes the country‚Äôs capacity to recover.

Her most striking statement came near the end: ‚ÄúAng stock market, mukhang para lang sa mayayaman. Pero kapag bumagsak ‚Äòyan, walang exempted.‚Äù

Aquino closed by reminding viewers that every Filipino ‚Äî regardless of income or status ‚Äî is connected to the country‚Äôs economic heartbeat. When corruption breaks public trust, she said, the shockwaves reach everyone.

BREAKING: ICI recommends plunder, graft raps vs Sen. Villanueva, Estrada, Zaldy Co, etal

The Independent Commission for Infrastructure has recommended criminal and administrative charges against several high-ranking officials, following the testimony of Henry Alcantara, a former DPWH district engineer in Bulacan.

Alcantara revealed how lawmakers allegedly coordinated with him to funnel infrastructure budgets into flood control projects‚Äîwhere kickbacks reportedly reached 25‚Äì30%, far higher than the usual 10% from other contracts.

Officials named in the report: 
‚Ä¢ Senator Joel Villanueva 
‚Ä¢ Senator Jinggoy Estrada 
‚Ä¢ Former Representative Zaldy Co 
‚Ä¢ Former Representative Mitch Cajayon Uy 
‚Ä¢ Former Public Works Undersecretary Roberto Bernardo 
‚Ä¢ COA Commissioner Mario Lipana

The scheme allegedly involved inserting projects into the National Expenditure Program (NEP) or the General Appropriations Act (GAA) through bicameral insertions, with bribes exchanged for project approvals and budget allocations.

Possible violations include plunder, bribery, and corruption of public officials under the Revised Penal Code and Republic Act 3019.

This is a developing story. 

Via Joel San Juan/ BM

Kinumpirma ng Manila Regional Trial Court (RTC) Branch 18 na peke ang affidavit na iniharap sa Senate Blue Ribbon Committee ni Orly Guteza, dating bodyguard ni Elizaldy "Zaldy" Co.

Sa isang 11-pahinang desisyon ni Executive Judge Carolina Icasiano-Sison, napatunayang peke ang pirma ng notary public na si Atty. Petchie Rose Espera matapos lumabas sa forensic examination na may malaking pagkakaiba sa kaniyang tunay na lagda.

Itinanggi rin ni Espera na siya ang nag-notarize ng dokumento at tinawag itong mapanlinlang at nakasisira sa kaniyang reputasyon.

Inatasan ng korte ang Department of Justice (DOJ) na magsampa ng falsification case laban kay Guteza at sa mga gumamit ng naturang dokumento.

Matapos ang 48 araw nang itatag ang Independent Commission for Infrastructure (ICI), napagtagpi-tagpi na rin ni ICI Chairman retired Justice Andres Reyes Jr. ang ‚Äòmodus‚Äô ng mga idinawit sa multi-bilyong pisong anomalya sa flood control projects, kabilang sina Senators Jinggoy Estrada at Joel Villanueva.

Dahil dito, inirekomenda ng ICI sa Office of the Ombudsman na sampahan ng mga kasong kriminal at administratibo ang dalawang senador at apat na iba pa na kinabibilangan nina dating Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) undersecretary Roberto Bernardo, dating Congressman Zaldy Co, Commission on Audit (COA) Commissioner Mario Lipana, at dating Congresswoman Mitch Cajayon-Uy.

‚ÄúThe testimonies and affidavits named the above-mentioned government officials or former government officials as primarily involved in these violations,‚Äù saad ni Reyes sa ginanap na press conference ngayong Miyerkules, Oktubre 29.

Ayon kay Andres, nagsisimula ang anomalya sa mga ‚Äúproponent‚Äù ng flood control project na miyembro ng Kamara o Senado. Ang mga mambabatas na umaaktong proponent ang siya namang magsasabi kay dating DPWH Bulacan district engineer Henry Alcantara na mayroon nang inalaang pondo para sa infrastructure project.

Sinabi ng ICI chairman na mas pinapaboran ng mga proponent ang flood control projects kumpara sa ibang proyektong imprastraktura dahil sa una ay mayroong 25 hanggang 30 porsiyentong kickback kumpara sa iba na kukubra lamang sila ng 10 porsiyento.

Pagkatapos nito ay gagawa si Alcantara ng listahan ng mga proyekto base sa budget na inilaan ng mga proponent. ‚ÄúThe list is given to Juan Carlo Rivera who would then transmit it to either the regional office in Bulacan or to the proponent itself.‚Äù

Kapag ang listahan ay ibinigay na sa DPWH director, ito ay isisingit na sa National Expenditure Program (NEP), ayon sa ICI chairman.

‚ÄúOn the other hand, if the list is given to the proponent itself, he or she would insert the projects in the House General Appropriations Bill or bicameral insertions wherein it would be reflected in the General Appropriations Act (GAA),‚Äù dagdag ni Reyes.

At kapag lumitaw na ang proyekto sa NEP o GAA, maghahanda na si Rivera ng summary ng mga proyekto habang si Alcantara naman ay pipili na ng kontratista na magpapatupad ng proyekto.

‚ÄúThis would trigger the payment on obligations or SOP to the proponent,‚Äù ani Reyes.

Ibibigay rin ang 10 porsiyentong advance payment mula sa budget allocation kapag inilabas na ang NEP habang ang natitirang 15 porsiyento ay ibabayad sa proponent kapag naipasa na ang GAA, inihayag din ni Reyes.

GROSS NEGLIGENCE, HINDI PLUNDER ‚Äì REMULLA

Ipinaliwanag ni Ombudsman Boying Remulla na maaaring managot si dating House Speaker at Leyte 1st District Rep. Martin Romualdez sa kasong gross negligence, kung walang matibay na ebidensiya para sa kasong plunder kaugnay ng mga iregularidad sa flood control projects.

Ayon kay Remulla:

‚ÄúAng isang pwedeng theory ay gross negligence. Speaker of the House siya [Martin Romualdez] at siya ang pumili ng chairman ng appropriations committee. Kahit di siya nag-participate dapat inalam niya rin kung anong nangyayari sa pondo ng bayan.‚Äù

Sa ilalim ng Revised Penal Code, ang gross negligence ay may parusang mula arresto mayor hanggang prision correccional, depende sa bigat ng kasong resulta kung ito‚Äôy sinadya.

Ang pahayag ni Remulla ay kasunod ng mga tanong kung dapat bang papanagutin si Romualdez sa mga iregularidad na lumitaw sa imbestigasyon ng Independent Commission for Infrastructure (ICI) hinggil sa mga ‚Äúghost flood control projects‚Äù na pinondohan ng bilyon-bilyong piso ng bayan.

NAITAKAS? 3 AIR ASSETS NI ZALDY CO, NAKALABAS NG BANSA 

Umani ng matinding tanong ang pag-alis ng tatlong air assets na konektado kay resigned Ako Bicol Rep. Zaldy Co, matapos kumpirmahin ng Civil Aviation Authority of the Philippines (CAAP) na nakalabas na ng bansa ang mga ito.

Ayon kay CAAP Director General Raul Del Rosario, unang lumipad palabas ng bansa ang isang helicopter noong August 20, sinundan ng Gulfstream 350 jet noong August 16, at isa pang helicopter noong September 11.

Batay sa opisyal na tala, nagtungo sa Singapore ang Gulfstream jet habang sa Kota Kinabalu, Malaysia naman dinala ang dalawang helicopter.

Amid the growing spotlight on bribery and ‚Äúgift-giving‚Äù in flood control scandals, local governments that have enforced strict no-gift rules are drawing renewed public respect for showing that ethical governance can start at the local level.

Naga City is at the center of this renewed push. Former Vice President and now Mayor @431221529830437 issued Executive Order No. 58 on October 22, institutionalizing a Comprehensive No Gift Policy that applies to all officials and employees of the city government. The order bans the direct or indirect solicitation or acceptance of any gift, gratuity, favor, entertainment, loan, discount, service, or anything of monetary value connected to official functions.

The EO also bars indirect acceptance through family members, close friends, housemates, agents, or any person acting on behalf of the official. It identifies high-risk areas where strict adherence is crucial: procurement and contract management, permitting and licensing, inspections and enforcement, recruitment and promotions, and financial transactions. Gifts from regulated entities‚Äîthose applying for or holding permits, licenses, or contracts with the city‚Äîare explicitly prohibited, including sponsored travel or entertainment.

While broad in scope, the EO allows strictly limited exceptions such as unsolicited tokens of nominal value, gifts from close family given purely out of personal affection, and protocolary gifts exchanged during official functions, provided they are recorded. Institutional donations are only allowed if made through formal agreements and subject to public disclosure.

A reporting and disposition mechanism is built into the policy. Any gift that exceeds nominal value or falls outside the exceptions must be reported to the Accountability Review Committee (ARC) within five working days. The ARC is tasked to document, register, and dispose of the gift appropriately. All offices are required to display ‚ÄúNo Gift Policy‚Äù posters, include ‚ÄúNo Gift Clauses‚Äù in contracts and bid documents, and actively inform the public of the prohibition.

Violations carry real consequences‚Äîadministrative penalties such as reprimand, suspension, or dismissal, and potential criminal prosecution under Republic Acts 3019 and 6713 and other anti-graft laws.

Robredo explained, ‚ÄúThe institutionalization of a comprehensive ‚ÄòNo Gift Policy‚Äô is a safeguard against conflicts of interest, corruption, and even the appearance of partiality or undue influence. Public office is a public trust, and we must always uphold that trust.‚Äù

In Kidapawan City, Mayor Jose Paolo Evangelista enforced a no-gift policy immediately upon assuming office, covering both city and barangay officials. ‚ÄúWe are paid by the government; gifts and tips are not necessary to perform our tasks,‚Äù Evangelista said. His transparency drive includes livestreaming all procurement sessions through the city‚Äôs Bids and Awards Committee to allow real-time public monitoring of transactions.

Evangelista also banned the use of titles like ‚ÄúHonorable‚Äù for elected city officials, emphasizing that public service is a duty, not a status symbol. Likewise, the posting of names and photos of politicians on publicly funded projects has been prohibited. The city‚Äôs policy framework is designed to reduce opportunities for political patronage and to reinforce impartiality in government transactions. The administration‚Äôs governance reforms are closely tied to supporting farmers, fisherfolk, cooperatives, 4Ps beneficiaries, and other community sectors, making transparency a working principle rather than a slogan.

The tightening of rules is not limited to local cities like Naga and Kidapawan. Vice President @338895877931805 has the same policy in place in her office, continuing a strict no-gift stance she enforced even during her time as mayor of Davao City. This was confirmed by her ally, Senator @51465411046762, in a Facebook post highlighting her long-standing adherence to the rule. Padilla also noted that Duterte maintains this policy even when she is abroad, emphasizing that she does not accept gifts or favors in any form.

That governance approach is consistent with how Davao City has also led reforms to remove personal credit or branding from public service. It was one of the first LGUs to stop placing politicians‚Äô names and faces on donations and relief goods during Sara Duterte‚Äôs mayoralty. The practice was recently reinforced through Executive Order No. 09, Series of 2025, signed on June 19 by Vice Mayor @339529628722889, stepping in for former President and Mayor @92917744756893. The EO orders the removal of all signages, billboards, and tarpaulins bearing the names or faces of officials on government projects and donations, aligning with DILG Memorandum Circular 2010-101. It further institutionalizes Davao‚Äôs long-time stance against using public service for personal or political promotion.

Sen. Padilla has publicly pointed to Sara Duterte‚Äôs strict adherence to these governance principles as an example of ethical leadership.

These local initiatives are firmly anchored on long-standing national laws meant to curb bribery and influence-peddling. Republic Act 6713 or the Code of Conduct and Ethical Standards for Public Officials and Employees requires all public servants to avoid accepting gifts, favors, or benefits that may influence their official actions. Republic Act 3019, the Anti-Graft and Corrupt Practices Act, penalizes the act of receiving any consideration in connection with a government transaction. Presidential Decree 46 goes even further by prohibiting public officials from accepting gifts on any occasion, including holidays or celebrations, regardless of intent.

What sets Naga, Kidapawan, and Davao City apart is that they are applying these national laws through concrete local action‚Äîturning anti-graft provisions into day-to-day governance measures. By removing avenues for influence, cutting political branding, and institutionalizing accountability, these LGUs are closing the gray areas where bribery and corruption often thrive. If the same level of enforcement were applied at the national level, the systemic corruption exposed in flood control projects and other big-ticket programs would face far less space to operate.

When Transparency Turns into a Target

In June 2024, the Department of Public Works and Highways transmitted a routine memo: ‚ÄúConstruction of Missile Storage Facility, Naval Base Rafael Ramos (NBRR), Lapu-Lapu City, Cebu,‚Äù a ‚Ç±10-million project under the DPWH‚ÄìDND‚Äôs TIKAS program. On paper, it was just another defense line-item tucked inside the national budget. But when that phrase appeared on tarpaulins across Lapu-Lapu City, it became something else: a public announcement of a military weapons depot.

The Philippine Navy immediately reminded everyone of the stakes. In a carefully worded statement, it said that ‚Äúsensitive facilities must remain confidential to ensure operational security.‚Äù That was less a rebuke, more a warning: publicity can make an installation a target.

Local leaders, however, struck a different tone. Mayor and Representative Cindi Chan defended the tarps, framing them as accountability to taxpayers. ‚ÄúIf there were really security risks, the Navy would have told us,‚Äù she argued, adding that the city already hosts an air base and a naval base ‚Äî why hide this one? For her, the tarp was transparent.

But this is where the logic falters. Bases are visible by design; a missile storage facility is not. Publicizing a weapons depot does not strengthen deterrence ‚Äî it weakens it. The fact that the Navy raised OPSEC concerns shows that what might look like routine ‚Äútax transparency‚Äù on the ground is seen as strategic carelessness by the very institution meant to operate the facility.

And then there‚Äôs the politics. A ‚Ç±10-million allocation in a national defense budget is modest ‚Äî likely meant for design or early construction. The money itself is not the scandal. The scandal is how it was used as political branding: ‚ÄúThis is where your taxes go.‚Äù In doing so, a defense asset became a campaign prop. A line-item became a billboard. Governance blurred into self-promotion.

The larger question is not whether missile storage should be built ‚Äî that‚Äôs a matter of defense strategy. The question is why it had to be paraded in public. When leaders confuse optics with stewardship, they don‚Äôt just risk their reputation; they risk the safety of their own constituents.

Transparency is essential in democracy, but in defense, silence is not secrecy ‚Äî it is strategy. By advertising what should have been guarded, Lapu-Lapu‚Äôs leaders turned transparency into a liability. And in matters of national security, that is not just tone-deaf politics; it is reckless governance.

Marcoleta witness Orly Guteza's testimony falsified says Manila Court

Senator Lacson confirmed to OneNewsPH that the Executive judge of the Manila Regional Trial Court has completed the investigation into the alleged falsified notary of Guteza‚Äôs sworn statement, with the courts recommending that charges of falsification and pujury against Orly Guteza.

The Manila court has found the sworn statement of Senate witness Orly Guteza falsified, absolving notary public Petchie Rose Espera of any liability in the document‚Äôs notarization.

In an 11-page order dated Oct. 24, Executive Judge Carolina Iscasiano-Sison of the Manila Regional Trial Court Branch 18 said Espera appeared to be a ‚Äúvictim‚Äù of the falsification incident, as her signature and notarial details had been forged.

One of the basis for the executive judge‚Äôs ruling was a National Bureau of Investigation forensic analysis, which showed that the signature in Guteza‚Äôs sworn statement, compared with Espera‚Äôs standard signature, ‚Äúwere not written by one and the same person.‚Äù

Jinggoy Estrada‚Äôs 2024 SALN: The Numbers Don‚Äôt Lie, But They Do Raise Questions

Another year, another glossy Statement of Assets, Liabilities, and Net Worth from Senator Jinggoy Estrada. On paper, his fortune is impressive: over ‚Ç±252 million in assets stacked high with condos, houses, jewelry, vehicles, and nearly ‚Ç±100 million in ‚Äúinvestments.‚Äù After subtracting liabilities of just ‚Ç±31 million, his net worth lands at a staggering ‚Ç±221 million.

But here‚Äôs the rub: for a lifelong politician, where does the sustained wealth come from? The math might be legal, but is it moral? Estrada‚Äôs long career has been shadowed by plunder charges, pork barrel scandals, and suspicions of political dynasties fattening themselves while ordinary Filipinos scrape by. When senators‚Äô families can casually declare luxury condos, sprawling lots, and eight-figure cash holdings, what message does that send to citizens who line up at food banks or face ballooning utility bills?

The SALN is meant to assure transparency, not showcase excess. What we see here is less about ‚Äúpublic service‚Äù and more about a dynasty‚Äôs private empire. While Estrada lists his half-brother JV Ejercito and his daughter Janelle Maria Ejercito as government officials, the family‚Äôs influence spreads far beyond kinship‚Äîit extends into the very fabric of policymaking.

Transparency should provoke accountability. Instead, these declarations read like a badge of untouchability. In a nation where minimum wage can‚Äôt keep up with rice prices, ‚Ç±221 million net worth isn‚Äôt just a number‚Äîit‚Äôs a mirror of the distance between our leaders and the people they claim to represent.

ESCUDERO REVEALED AS 'POOREST' SENATOR IN 2024 SALN; LISTS SISTER, UNCLE, AND COUSIN IN PUBLIC SERVICE

Sen. Chiz Escudero, who declared a net worth of ‚Ç±18.84 million in his 2024 Statement of Assets, Liabilities, and Net Worth (SALN), identified three relatives currently serving in government.

His sister, Rep. Marie Bernadette C. Escudero, represents the 1st District of Sorsogon in the House of Representatives; his paternal uncle, Ramon Escudero, serves as councilor in Casiguran, Sorsogon; and his paternal cousin, Kruniamar Antonio Escudero II, is the vice governor of Sorsogon province.

LACSON: DPWH DIVERTED ‚Ç±50B IN UNPROGRAMMED FUNDS FOR INFRA PROJECTS IN 2024

Senate President Pro Tempore Ping Lacson revealed that the Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) diverted no less than ‚Ç±50 billion from unprogrammed appropriations in the 2024 national budget for various infrastructure projects ‚Äî including ‚Ç±30 billion for flood control alone.

"Sa 2024, nakita ko ang dokumento, ang hinugot nila from unprogrammed appropriations, pumapalo ng P50B at P30B ang nakalagak sa flood control projects," Lacson said during an interview on DZBB. "Ibig sabihin nawili sila sa flood control projects na di tumatama sa master plan."

He said the appropriations were spread across several districts, enabling collusion between some lawmakers and DPWH officials.

"Talagang naabuso. Kasi nandiyan ang suki nila, suki ng mambabatas sa DPWH kaya tinambakan nila kaya naungusan ang education sector. Kaya sa 2025 tinodo nila, yan ang masama kasi nawili, kaya sumabog," he added.

Lacson welcomed the reforms being implemented by new DPWH Secretary Vince Dizon to align projects with the government's master plan, as well as the stance of Senate Finance Committee Chair Win Gatchalian not to fund projects outside it.

He also warned against the DPWH's alleged practice of substituting projects, saying it constitutes technical malversation.

"Pag nagpasa kami ng budget itemized yan... Pag iniba mo ang paglalagakan ng pondo, technical malversation yan, act pa lang, wala pang ninanakaw," he said.

On the proposed 2026 budget, Lacson said senators will move to delete around ‚Ç±42 billion in "ayuda" or social assistance funds lodged under unprogrammed appropriations, insisting that only foreign-assisted projects should remain under that category.

"Nagtira ang House sa unprogrammed appropriations ng ayuda. Ang naiwan doon P42 billion, tatanggalin namin yan," he said in an interview with One News. "Ilagay natin sa regular budget."

Lacson, who is known for his sharp scrutiny of the national budget, praised Gatchalian's handling of the Senate budget hearings.

"Maganda ang kanyang pag-aaral. Scrutiny niya maraming nalabas na maanomalya, questionable, red flag. I take my hat off to him," Lacson said.

@509428916202013 Abangan ang palusot ni Marcoleta at Defensor Attorney

Idineklara ng Manila Regional Trial Court (RTC) Branch 18 na ang lagda ni Atty. Petchie Rose Espera na nakalagay sa sworn statement ni dating Philippine Marine soldier Orly Guteza na may petsang Setyembre 24, 2025 na isinumite sa Senate Blue Ribbon Committee, ay hindi sa abogado dahil pineke lamang ito.

Sa 11-pahinang dokumento kung saan nakasaad ang resulta ng forensic examination ng National Bureau of Investigation (NBI), sinabi ni Manila RTC Branch 18 Executive Judge Carolina Icasiano-Sison na kinumpirma ng mga imbestigador na ang lagda sa affidavit ni Guteza at ang kanyang actual signature ay hindi rin tumutugma.

"Laboratory comparative examination conducted on the specimens submitted using the stereoscopic microscope, Video Spectral Comparator (VSC4000), forensic image analyzer, magnifying hand lens, and photographic enlargements (comparison chart) reveals the existence of significant fundamental differences in handwriting characteristics and habits between the questioned and the standard specimen signatures PETCHIE ROSE G. ESPERA," nakasaad sa report ng NBI na isinumite sa korte.

Dahil dito, inirekomenda ni Sison ang paghahain ng kasong falsification laban kay Guteza at iba pang nasa likod ng pagprisinta ng kontrobersiyal na dokumento kung saan nakalagay ang pekeng lagda ni Espera at iba pang kuwestiyunableng impormasyon na nakasaad doon.

Si Guteza ay ang "surprise witness" na ipinakilala ni Sen. Rodante Marcoleta sa pagdinig ng Senate Blue Ribbon Committee noong Setyembre 25, 2025.

Pinabulaanan ni Quezon City 1st District Rep. Arjo Atayde ang pagkakaroon umano ng ghost infrastructure projects sa kaniyang distrito.

Sinabi ito ng kongresista kasunod ng pag-inspeksyon sa pito umanong ghost flood control at drainage projects sa kanilang lugar. Aniya, kumpleto o nagpapatuloy ang mga proyekto, may maayos na documentation, tamang coordinates, at photographic evidence.

WHY BBM SOUNDED OFF-KEY IN ASEAN
Opinion | Rob Rances

PBBM came out swinging sa ASEAN Summit‚Äîblasts on China, full spotlight moment. 

On the surface: bold leadership.
Strategic? Not quite.

Kasi habang siya ay todo-banat, host country Malaysia calmly said: ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs handle this internally.‚Äù

Translation: ASEAN plays chess, not karaoke.

I. THE ASEAN WAY: QUIET, NOT CONFRONTATIONAL

Since 1967, ASEAN‚Äôs strength has never been its volume‚Äîbut its discipline. 

The ‚ÄúASEAN Way‚Äù rests on three pillars: non-interference, consensus, and quiet diplomacy.

‚Ä¢ When Vietnam clashed with China over the Paracels in the 1970s, ASEAN didn‚Äôt grandstand; it brokered calm through neutrality.

‚Ä¢ When Myanmar‚Äôs junta drew global condemnation, ASEAN didn‚Äôt issue fiery condemnations‚Äîit sent quiet envoys and pushed ‚Äúconstructive engagement.‚Äù

‚Ä¢ Even with South China Sea tensions, ASEAN avoids naming and shaming. Instead, it works through code-of-conduct talks and collective restraint to avoid escalation.

It‚Äôs an orchestra that values harmony over solo performances.

But in this summit, BBM may have thought he was leading the song‚Äîbut, I think, he ended up off-key. 

ASEAN countries like Singapore, Indonesia, and Malaysia balance US-China tensions through strategic ambiguity. But the Philippines, under BBM‚Äôs tone, sounded more like Washington‚Äôs frontman than an independent voice.

II. PRINCIPLED, NOT PROVOCATIVE

Yes, dapat ipaglaban ang soberanya natin, pero may tamang tono at timing. Diplomacy isn‚Äôt a concert; it‚Äôs choreography. Every word counts.

ASEAN‚Äôs real power is subtlety. Every pause has purpose. Every silence has strategy.

And here we are‚Äî‚Äúblasting‚Äù in the room, standing alone in a spotlight that perhaps no one else asked for.

In a region guided by quiet consensus, I think BBM‚Äôs message sounded a bit out of rhythm. At a table meant for strategy, his message seemed aimed more at visibility than unity.

III. MY TAKE 

Yes, we must defend our sovereignty and our fishermen. Protect the West Philippine Sea. 

But remember, sa ASEAN, hindi pinaparangalan ang pinaka-matalas magsalita kundi ang marunong mag-strategize.

So, Mr. President, stand firm‚Ä¶ but stand wise.

The best leaders don‚Äôt win by ‚Äúblasting.‚Äù

‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢

Disclaimer: This commentary reflects my personal analysis and interpretation of recent ASEAN developments. It is not intended as an attack on any individual or institution but as a perspective on how tone, timing, and diplomacy shape regional perception and strategy.

SNOW WHITE AND THE SEVEN ARTICLES OF IMPEACHMENT?

Vice President Sara Duterte dressed as Disney princess Snow White for Halloween this year‚Äîjust months after surviving an impeachment attempt at the House of Representatives.

Photos of Duterte in her Halloween costume were shared online by several of her blogger-supporters, drawing renewed public attention amid her ongoing political controversies.

On February 5, the House of Representatives impeached Duterte and immediately transmitted the complaint to the Senate, with 215 lawmakers‚Äîmore than the one-third requirement under the Constitution‚Äîsigning in support.

The complaint consisted of seven articles of impeachment, citing betrayal of public trust, culpable violations of the Constitution, graft and corruption, bribery, and other high crimes. Duterte was accused of plotting the assassination of top government officials, misusing confidential funds of the Office of the Vice President and the Department of Education, amassing unexplained wealth, and failing to fully disclose her assets in her SALN. It also alleged acts of bribery, destabilization, sedition, and insurrection, as well as the totality of her conduct in office, which was said to constitute grave violations of the Constitution and an abuse of public trust.

However, the Senate later voted 19‚Äì4‚Äì1 on August 6 to archive the impeachment complaint, following a Supreme Court ruling declaring the proceedings "null and void ab initio."

The High Court held that the complaint violated the one-year bar rule and deprived Duterte of due process, effectively voiding the case from the start.

Then-Senate Minority Leader Tito Sotto, then-Senate Deputy Minority Leader Risa Hontiveros, Sen. Kiko Pangilinan, and Sen. Bam Aquino voted against the motion to archive, citing a pending House motion for reconsideration.

The House, through the Solicitor General, has since asked the Supreme Court to reconsider its ruling.

Sinabi ni SP Pro Tempore Ping Lacson na batay sa CCTV footage ng Senado, dumaan muna raw sa opisina ni Senador Rodante Marcoleta si Orly Guteza bago pa ito tuluyang bumababa sa session hall noong September 25 para sa flood control hearing.

Sa nasabing footage, 8:27am nakarating si Guteza sa institusyon at nanatili muna ito sa opisina ni Marcoleta ng humigit-kumulang 30 minuto bago bumababa sa gallery ng session hall kung saan nagaganap ang pagdinig.

Maalala, si Guteza ang ipinresentang testigo ni Marcoleta sa Senate Blue Ribbon Committee na siyang lumapit daw sa kanya para magboluntaryong magsalita.

Sa testimonya ni Guteza, sinabi niya na kabilang daw siya sa mga taong naghahatid ng maletang naglalaman ng pera sa bahay nina dating HS Martin Romualdez at dating congressman Elizaldy Co.

Samantala, ipinaalam din ng senador na natuklasan ng Executive Judge ng Manila Regional Trial Court na hindi tugma ang pirma sa affidavit ni Guteza sa tunay na pirma ni Atty. Petchie Espera.

ASEAN Plays Chess not Karaoke‚ö°
---------

WHY BBM SOUNDED OFF-KEY IN ASEAN
Opinion | Rob Rances

PBBM came out swinging sa ASEAN Summit‚Äîblasts on China, full spotlight moment. 

On the surface: bold leadership.
Strategic? Not quite.

Kasi habang siya ay todo-banat, host country Malaysia calmly said: ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs handle this internally.‚Äù

Translation: ASEAN plays chess, not karaoke.

I. THE ASEAN WAY: QUIET, NOT CONFRONTATIONAL

Since 1967, ASEAN‚Äôs strength has never been its volume‚Äîbut its discipline. 

The ‚ÄúASEAN Way‚Äù rests on three pillars: non-interference, consensus, and quiet diplomacy.

‚Ä¢ When Vietnam clashed with China over the Paracels in the 1970s, ASEAN didn‚Äôt grandstand; it brokered calm through neutrality.

‚Ä¢ When Myanmar‚Äôs junta drew global condemnation, ASEAN didn‚Äôt issue fiery condemnations‚Äîit sent quiet envoys and pushed ‚Äúconstructive engagement.‚Äù

‚Ä¢ Even with South China Sea tensions, ASEAN avoids naming and shaming. Instead, it works through code-of-conduct talks and collective restraint to avoid escalation.

It‚Äôs an orchestra that values harmony over solo performances.

But in this summit, BBM may have thought he was leading the song‚Äîbut, I think, he ended up off-key. 

ASEAN countries like Singapore, Indonesia, and Malaysia balance US-China tensions through strategic ambiguity. But the Philippines, under BBM‚Äôs tone, sounded more like Washington‚Äôs frontman than an independent voice.

II. PRINCIPLED, NOT PROVOCATIVE

Yes, dapat ipaglaban ang soberanya natin, pero may tamang tono at timing. Diplomacy isn‚Äôt a concert; it‚Äôs choreography. Every word counts.

ASEAN‚Äôs real power is subtlety. Every pause has purpose. Every silence has strategy.

And here we are‚Äî‚Äúblasting‚Äù in the room, standing alone in a spotlight that perhaps no one else asked for.

In a region guided by quiet consensus, I think BBM‚Äôs message sounded a bit out of rhythm. At a table meant for strategy, his message seemed aimed more at visibility than unity.

III. MY TAKE 

Yes, we must defend our sovereignty and our fishermen. Protect the West Philippine Sea. 

But remember, sa ASEAN, hindi pinaparangalan ang pinaka-matalas magsalita kundi ang marunong mag-strategize.

So, Mr. President, stand firm‚Ä¶ but stand wise.

The best leaders don‚Äôt win by ‚Äúblasting.‚Äù

‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢

Disclaimer: This commentary reflects my personal analysis and interpretation of recent ASEAN developments. It is not intended as an attack on any individual or institution but as a perspective on how tone, timing, and diplomacy shape regional perception and strategy.
