The Discayas: Scam Artists in Witness Clothing

They walk into hearings like celebrities, heads high, faces smug, as if the nation owes them applause. But beneath that smug grin lies the stench of rot. Pacifico ‚ÄúCurlee‚Äù Discaya and Cezarah ‚ÄúSarah‚Äù Discaya aren‚Äôt the heroes they pretend to be. They‚Äôre not truth-tellers. They‚Äôre the fingerprints on every scam the government‚Äôs flood-control projects ever saw.

These two didn‚Äôt stumble into corruption, they swam in it. Their names pop up in thousands of bids, in province after province, from the Department of Public Works and Highways to local contractors who all swear they‚Äôve seen those same signatures in the same shady circles. Every thread investigators pull ends with the same pattern: the Discayas at the center.

And now they have the gall to stand before the public and demand protection, acting like martyrs who ‚Äújust want to tell the truth.‚Äù Truth? Let‚Äôs call it what it is, damage control.

The Crocodile Tears

Their statements don‚Äôt line up. One day they claim they were ‚Äúused.‚Äù The next day they act like masterminds who suddenly found conscience. Even senators noticed: their stories shift depending on who‚Äôs asking. They cry foul when questioned, then pose for cameras flashing finger hearts like influencers on a break. That‚Äôs not remorse, that‚Äôs mockery.

How can the same people who fattened themselves on fake contracts now sell themselves as witnesses? The hypocrisy is thicker than the mud their bogus flood projects left behind.

Not the ‚ÄúLeast Guilty‚Äù -  The Most Involved

Let‚Äôs be clear: to become a state witness, the law says you must be among the least guilty. The Discayas? They‚Äôre the opposite. They weren‚Äôt bystanders, they were architects.

They set up the shell firms, handled the bidding, and moved the cash. Even lawmakers have said it: these two are indispensable to the scam itself. Without them, the whole racket collapses, which makes them ringleaders, not minor players.

So why are they being treated like delicate informants instead of prime suspects? Because that‚Äôs how this system always plays its game, turn crooks into choirboys when the heat‚Äôs on.

The People Pay Twice

Flood victims still drown in substandard projects, crumbling dikes, useless canals, roads that vanish with the rain. Meanwhile, the Discayas built mansions and now beg for mercy. The only ‚Äúwitness protection‚Äù they deserve is from the people they cheated, because the rage out here is real.

You don‚Äôt get to rob the nation blind, pocket the flood money, and then claim sainthood when the house burns down. Return the loot. Face the music. Then talk. Until then, every word from your mouths is just another lie dressed in courtroom language.

Curlee and Sarah Discaya are not heroes. They are co-conspirators turned opportunists, trying to rewrite their roles as victims of a system they helped poison. Their testimonies are selective. Their motives are selfish. And their sudden moral awakening? Convenient.

To let them slip into witness protection is not justice, it‚Äôs mockery of justice. It‚Äôs rewarding the very hands that bled public funds dry. The people deserve full truth, full restitution, and full punishment.

Until that happens, let‚Äôs call them what they are: Not witnesses. Not whistle-blowers. Just scammers trying to dodge the flood they themselves unleashed.

DISCAYAS, 'DI KUWALIPIKADO MAGING 'STATE WITNESS' - ASST. OMBUDSMAN

Sinabi ng isang opisyal ng Office of the Ombudsman na hindi na maaaring matanggap ang mag-asawang kontratista na sina Curle at Sarah Discaya bilang mga "state witness" dahil sa "uncooperative behavior" nila sa mga imbestigasyon sa multi-bilyong pisong anomalya sa flood control projects.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs absolutely no chance that they can even become state witnesses anymore, because of their statement that they are uncooperative, then they are deemed to be hostile witnesses and can only be charged as respondents in the future, accused in the case of malversation of public funds, of falsification of public documents, and all the other crimes that they were a part of,‚Äù sabi ni Assistant Ombudsman Mico Clavano sa press conference ngayong Lunes, Oktubre 27.

Sinabi pa ni Clavano na dahil sa "uncooperative behavior" ng mag-asawang Discaya sa mga nakaraang imbestigasyon ng Kongreso, sa halip na matanggap bilang mga "state witness" kalaunan ay lumabas pa na ang dalawa ay "hostile witnesses." 

Malalim din umano ang naging kutsabahan sa pagitan ng mga Discaya at mga tiwaling opisyal ng Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) na nasa likod ng "ghost" flood control projects at ilang opisyal ng gobyerno, dahilan upang makakomisyon umano sila ng bilyun-bilyon.

‚ÄúWe know that they joined over 4,000 bids around the country, and in whatever scheme or scam that we saw within the DPWH, they are part of it,‚Äù dagdag ni Clavano.

Matatandaan na si Sen. Rodante Marcoleta ang unang nagrekomenda sa Department of Justice (DOJ) na tanggapin ang Discaya couple bilang mga "state witness" subalit hinarang ito ni noo'y DOJ Secretary Jesus Crispin Remulla dahil may mga nakita itong indikasyon na pinoprotektahan umano ng dalawa si dating pangulong Rodrigo Dutere sa flood control scam.

‚ÄúSo that is their choice, if they want to be uncooperative, then the government has no choice but to run after them with every ounce of effort that we can muster,‚Äù dagdag ni Clavano.

The Office of the Ombudsman is preparing to file graft and corruption charges against former Ako Bicol Representative @763116735601112 over alleged anomalies in flood control projects. Ombudsman Jesus Crispin @29666241887838 confirmed that several criminal cases are set to be filed before the Sandiganbayan within 30 days, with Co among the officials expected to face prosecution.

The controversy revolves around a ‚Ç±289.5 million flood control project along the Mag-Asawang Tubig River in Naujan, Oriental Mindoro. The Independent Commission for Infrastructure (ICI), formed by Malaca√±ang to audit public works, discovered major irregularities that included incomplete and substandard construction, falsified accomplishment reports, and payments made for phases of the project that were never finished. The ICI‚Äôs audit also found that several documents appeared to have been backdated to justify fund releases, prompting the commission to recommend graft, malversation, and falsification charges against Co and officials of the @392192773701614.

The ICI identified Sunwest Construction and Development Corp. as the project‚Äôs contractor. The company has long been associated with Co, raising conflict-of-interest concerns. Investigators also uncovered alleged budget insertions and kickbacks linked to other flood control allocations in Bulacan, broadening the investigation into multiple DPWH-funded projects.

During Senate budget deliberations for the Ombudsman‚Äôs 2026 funding, Remulla said several current and former lawmakers were implicated in similar cases. He confirmed that Co‚Äôs name surfaced prominently in the Mindoro investigation. A subpoena has been issued to Co and 17 others, directing them to file counter-affidavits within 10 days.

Co, who resigned from Congress earlier this year amid the controversy, has denied all allegations. He maintains that the projects underwent proper bidding and complied with government procedures. As of October 24, 2025, the Ombudsman said it is finalizing documents before formally submitting them to the anti-graft court.

If the case proceeds, it could become one of the most high-profile corruption prosecutions under the Marcos administration, testing the government‚Äôs resolve to pursue accountability among politically influential¬†figures.

DPWH BUDGET, ISUSUMITE NA SA SENATE PLENARY  

Inaprubahan ng Senate Committee on Finance ang P625.78-bilyong proposed budget ng Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) para sa 2026.  

Kalakip nito ang kondisyong maibigay muna ng ahensya ang mga hinihinging dokumento upang matugunan ang ilang ‚Äúred flags‚Äù na proyekto. 

Nangako naman si DPWH Sec. Vince Dizon na magsusumite ang ahensya ng karagdagang detalye at dokumento sa Biyernes, Oct. 31. 

‚ÄúThe budget of the DPWH is now deemed submitted for plenary‚Äôs consideration subject to the discussion and the submission of documents requested,‚Äù saad ni committee chairperson Sen. Win Gatchalian.

SUPORTADO SI SEN. LACSON

Suportado ni acting Senate Blue Ribbon Committee chairman Sen. Erwin Tulfo ang pagbabalik ni Sen. Ping Lacson bilang pinuno ng komite.

Ayon kay Tulfo, handa siyang magbigay-daan sa pagbabalik ni Lacson para pangunahan ang imbestigasyon sa flood control anomalies.

Inaasahang magpapatuloy ang mga pagdinig ng komite sa Nov. 10 kung saan may ihaharap na bagong testigo si Lacson na kilala ang mga tinatawag nilang "congtractors."

DPWH BUDGET, PASADO NA SA SENATE COMMITTEE

Inaprubahan na ng Senate Committee on Finance ang panukalang 2026 budget ng Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH). Isusumite na ito para sa plenary consideration.

Pinasusumite naman ang kagawaran ng karagdagang dokumento para tugunan ang "red flags" sa panukalang budget.

üìù Commentary: A Trillion-Peso Tragedy Must Not Be Repeated

The unfolding corruption cases involving over a trillion pesos in flood control funds are a sobering reminder of how public trust can be eroded when accountability is delayed‚Äîor denied.

We‚Äôve seen this before. The PDAF scandal dragged on for years, exhausting the public‚Äôs patience, only to end with acquittals and no real reckoning. The lesson? A long and tiring process without transparency leads to impunity.

This time must be different.

‚Ä¢ We need swift and impartial investigations.
‚Ä¢ We demand full transparency in the use of public funds.
‚Ä¢ We insist on true accountability, not just legal technicalities.

Let this be the moment we break the cycle. The Filipino people deserve justice‚Äînot another forgotten scandal.

CHIZ: LGU PARTICIPATION IN BUDGET PROCESS SHOULD BE A MUST

Sen. Chiz Escudero has called on Congress to demonstrate its commitment to genuine budget reform by giving local government units (LGUs) a greater role in identifying and implementing infrastructure projects under the 2026 national budget.

With deliberations on the proposed ‚Ç±6.35-trillion budget still ongoing, Escudero urged the Senate Committee on Finance and the House Committee on Appropriations to allow LGUs to play a more active role in planning infrastructure projects to prevent abuses in the exercise of the "power of the purse."

"Ang maaaring gawin agad ng mga pinuno ng Committee on Finance ng Senado at ng Appropriations Committee ng Kamara ay bigyan ng mas malaking papel ang ating mga LGUs sa usapin ng infrastructure projects. Ang mga senador at kongresista ay nariyan lamang para makinig at bigyan daan ang mga pangangailangan ng ating mga taongbayan," Escudero said.

In a letter to Senate Finance Committee Chairperson Win Gatchalian, Escudero proposed that the endorsement of Regional Development Councils (RDCs) be made a mandatory requirement for infrastructure projects included in the General Appropriations Act (GAA). He said this reform could be implemented through a general or special provision in the 2026 GAA even before the passage of his proposed Grassroots Infrastructure Planning and Budgeting Act (Senate Bill No. 1459).

"It is unlikely that Congress will have time to pass the bill, but we can already include a provision in the 2026 GAA to implement the same and start the process of cleaning up the budget of unnecessary or worse, non-existing or ghost projects," he said.

Escudero explained that requiring RDC endorsements would help ensure that projects are relevant to local needs and protect public funds from corruption and redundancy.

"This will go a long way in preventing the inclusion of projects that are redundant, prone to corruption and have absolutely no benefit for the communities and people where these are situated," he added.

The senator cited revelations from recent flood control project investigations, where many LGUs said they were not consulted before projects were included in the National Expenditure Program (NEP).

"Ang mga LGU ang mas nakakaalam kung ano ang kailangan ng kanilang mga lugar pagdating sa mga infrastructure projects. Kaya nararapat at dapat lang na sila ang unang kinakausap bago pa mabuo ang NEP at sa pag-implementa ng mga proyektong ito para walang nasasayang na pera ng taumbayan," Escudero said.

Under Senate Bill No. 1459, the RDC endorsement requirement will apply to projects of key agencies, including the Departments of Agriculture, Education, Health, Information and Communications Technology, Interior and Local Government, National Defense, Public Works and Highways, and Transportation.

Escudero said the measure embodies the long-standing principle of bottom-up budgeting to make the budget process more efficient, accountable, and responsive to the needs of the people.

Education Secretary @793211114310994 slammed the Department of Public Works and Highways (@392192773701614) for prioritizing flood control projects instead of addressing the classroom shortage, after revealing that only 22 out of 1,000 targeted classrooms have been completed for 2025.

‚ÄúMukhang nawili sila doon sa flood control, sa totoo lang eh. Parang hindi na naging priority ‚Äôyung pagtayo ng classroom,‚Äù Angara told reporters in Malaca√±ang on Tuesday.

Since 2018, the DPWH has been in charge of constructing @767491417819876-funded classrooms. But Angara said the agency‚Äôs workload and red tape have caused delays. To speed up the process, he plans to let local government units (LGUs) take part in classroom construction.

‚ÄúGusto na namin baguhin ‚Äôyung sistema‚Ä¶ Palagay ko, mas bibilis ang proseso. Sa dami na rin ng ginagawa ng DPWH, nahirapan na rin sila,‚Äù Angara said.

According to the education secretary, the backlog under the 2025 Basic Education Facilities Fund (BEFF) has reached 900 classrooms, while the nationwide shortage now stands at around 150,000.

Despite the setbacks, Angara expressed confidence in newly appointed DPWH Secretary Vince Dizon and said he expects faster implementation under his watch.

To further boost classroom construction, Angara said the DepEd plans to revive public-private partnerships (PPP), a model used under former Education Secretary Brother Armin Luistro. ‚ÄúDoon, imbis na magpapabid ka ng isang building lamang, nagpapabid ka ng isang libong classroom. Sabay-sabay ‚Äôyun,‚Äù he said.

In a separate statement, the DepEd criticized the ‚Äúunacceptable‚Äù pace of construction, saying, ‚ÄúHindi katanggap-tanggap na 22 classrooms lang ang nagawa sa ilalim ng nakaraang pamunuan ng DPWH, sa kabila ng pondong ibinigay at tulong mula sa DepEd.‚Äù

The department announced that starting 2026, it will channel classroom construction funds directly to LGUs, the AFP Corps of Engineers, or private contractors instead of the DPWH.

‚ÄúNakakapanghinayang talaga dahil alam natin ‚Äôyun ang kailangan ng bayan‚Ä¶ Kailangan natin para umunlad ‚Äôyung mga kabataan,‚Äù¬†Angara¬†said.

A Nation Held Hostage by Corruption: A Call to Inner Strength and Quiet Joy

We are living in a time when corruption feels invincible‚Äîtoo entrenched, too protected, too shameless. From ghost flood control projects to the Napoles scandal, from two presidential impeachments to the betrayal of EDSA‚Äôs promise, we have seen it all. We ousted a dictator, only to welcome his son and witness the worst corruption in Philippine history.

Today, our Congress, Senate, and Executive branch are riddled with impunity. Our judiciary moves at a glacial pace. The powerful protect their own. The corrupt are not punished‚Äîthey are recycled, defended, and even celebrated.

It is tempting to say: Wala nang pag-asa.
That we are wasting our time.
That justice will never come.

But in the face of this despair, we must choose a different kind of resistance‚Äînot loud, not violent, but enduring.

Let us be calm. Let us stay strong.

Let us protect what we still have: our health, our families, our work, our simple joys. Let us raise children who know the difference between brilliance and integrity. Let us honor the quiet heroes‚Äînurses, teachers, farmers, and honest workers‚Äîwho build this country from the ground up.

Let us find happiness in the small things:

‚Ä¢ A child‚Äôs laughter at breakfast
‚Ä¢ A nurse‚Äôs gentle touch in the ICU
‚Ä¢ A teacher‚Äôs handwritten lesson plan
‚Ä¢ A farmer‚Äôs harvest after the storm
‚Ä¢ A friend‚Äôs message that says, ‚ÄúKaya pa.‚Äù

These are not distractions from the fight. They are the reason for it.

We may not see the end of corruption in our lifetime. But we can live lives that reject it. We can build communities that resist it. We can speak truths that expose it.

And we can pray‚Äînot just for miracles, but for the strength to endure, the wisdom to discern, and the courage to keep going.

The Filipino people are not weak. We are wounded, yes‚Äîbut we are still standing.
We are still loving.
We are still laughing.
We are still hoping.

And that, in itself, is a form of victory.

#RelentlessForChange
Tony Leachon

üõë Statement on Flood Control Anomalies and the Fight for Integrity

Dr. Tony Leachon 

More than a month into the investigation, the revelations from the Independent Commission for Infrastructure (ICI) are deeply troubling. The disclosure by Chairperson Andres Reyes Jr.‚Äîthat flood control projects are ‚Äúsold‚Äù and divided among participants‚Äîconfirms what many citizens have long suspected: that corruption is not just a flaw in the system, but a design.

In the face of this, we ask: is there a silver lining?

It‚Äôs hard to see one when powerful individuals with money and influence continue to defend their own wrongdoing, conceal the truth, and cover their tracks. 

For many of us, hope feels distant. Trust in institutions is eroded. The suffering of ordinary people‚Äîthose who endure floods, displacement, and neglect‚Äîis compounded by betrayal.

And yet, we will not yield.

We will continue to fight for our rights and principles. We will protect our inner peace and health, even as we confront injustice. We will speak truth, demand accountability, and stand with the few leaders who choose integrity over convenience.

To those who still serve with honor: thank you. May your courage ripple outward.

To the sick, the displaced, the anxious families, and the tireless health workers: we see you. We pray for you.

And to every Filipino who refuses to be silenced‚Äîmay light and love guide our path, even in the darkest storms.

Section 1: Term Limits for Members of Congress
No person shall be elected to the House of Representatives more than six times, nor to the Senate more than twice. Service for more than half a term shall be deemed a full term for the purposes of this limit. This limitation shall apply prospectively and shall not affect terms served prior to ratification.

Section 2: Enforcement
Congress shall have the power to enforce this article by appropriate legislation. Federal courts shall have jurisdiction to review and remedy violations.

Section 3: Effective Date
This article shall take effect two years after ratification, allowing for an orderly transition.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
(This proposal draws from historical precedents and modern recommendations, aiming for a balanced 12-year maximum in each chamber to foster rotation while preserving institutional knowledge.)

1. What Are the Optimal Limits?
Based on a synthesis of historical debates, empirical studies, and proposed legislation, the optimal term limits for the U.S. Congress are:

Six terms (12 years) for the House of Representatives and
Two terms (12 years) for the Senate. 

This structure aligns with common recommendations from think tanks, polls, and legislative proposals, such as those from U.S. Term Limits and bipartisan bills like H.J. Res. 12 (119th Congress), which suggest similar caps to ensure parity in service length across chambers.

Shorter limits (e.g., three House terms or one Senate term) risk excessive turnover and loss of expertise, while longer ones (e.g., unlimited as current) enable entrenchment. A 12-year cap provides enough time for legislators to gain proficiency‚Äîtypically 4-6 years per studies on legislative effectiveness‚Äîbefore mandating fresh perspectives.

2. Why?
These limits are optimal because they balance the founders' emphasis on "rotation in office" with the practical need for experienced governance, as evidenced by historical writings and modern analyses. Founding fathers like Thomas Jefferson advocated for rotation to prevent abuse and corruption, warning that without it, offices could become hereditary or dominated by entrenched interests; he specifically favored limits for higher offices to ensure periodic renewal. George Mason and Benjamin Franklin supported similar ideas during the Constitutional Convention, viewing term limits as a safeguard against monarchy-like perpetuity, though the final Constitution omitted them, trusting elections instead.

James Madison, in Federalist No. 53, argued against rigid limits, prioritizing accumulated knowledge, but acknowledged rotation's value in preventing "perpetual incumbency." Other American thinkers, such as those in the Anti-Federalist Papers, echoed this, fearing unlimited terms would lead to an aristocratic class.

Empirical studies reinforce this: Research from the University of Chicago's Center for Effective Government indicates that 8-12 years allows for policy expertise without the distortions of long-term incumbency, such as reduced responsiveness to constituents.

State-level experiments (e.g., 15 states with legislative term limits) show that 12-year caps increase diversity and innovation but avoid the chaos of shorter terms, like California's initial 6-8 year limits, which led to rushed policymaking. Public support is overwhelming‚Äî87% in Pew surveys‚Äîcrossing party lines, reflecting a consensus that 12 years strikes the right balance between renewal and stability.

3. Pros and Cons of Term Limits
Term limits have been debated since the founding era, with objective analyses from sources like Britannica, Brookings, and NPR highlighting trade-offs. Below is a balanced overview, drawing from academic and think tank research.
Pros:
1. Reduces Incumbent Advantages and Corruption: Limits counteract the 90%+ reelection rates driven by name recognition, fundraising edges, and gerrymandering, fostering competition and reducing special interest influence, as noted in Heritage Foundation analyses. Founders like Jefferson saw this as essential to prevent "abuse" from prolonged power.
2. Promotes Fresh Ideas and Diversity: Mandatory turnover brings new perspectives, increasing representation of underrepresented groups (e.g., women and minorities in term-limited states) and aligning with the founders' rotation principle to avoid stagnation.
3. Shifts Focus to Policy Over Reelection: Legislators spend less time campaigning, potentially making bolder decisions, as supported by ACE Electoral Knowledge Network studies.
4. Enhances Accountability: Echoing Anti-Federalist concerns, limits prevent a "professional politician" class, returning officials to civilian life as Jefferson envisioned.

Cons:
1. Loss of Institutional Knowledge and Expertise: Experienced members handle complex issues better; studies show term limits lead to less effective legislation and higher reliance on unelected staff or lobbyists, per Brookings and University of Chicago research. Madison argued this in Federalist Papers, valuing tenure for stability.
2. Increases Lobbyist Influence: Novice legislators may defer to external experts, amplifying special interests‚Äîa pattern observed in term-limited state legislatures.
3. Potential for Lame-Duck Ineffectiveness: Final-term members might prioritize personal gains or neglect duties, as noted in NPR analyses.
4. Undermines Voter Choice: Elections already serve as "term limits," per founders' faith in democracy; imposing caps overrides voter will, as ruled in U.S. Term Limits v. Thornton (1995). It may also deter qualified candidates without wealth or connections.

Solving for the Best Solution
Considering the founders' mixed views‚Äîfavoring rotation (Jefferson, Mason) but prioritizing elections and experience (Madison)‚Äîand objective modern evidence, the best solution is a constitutional amendment with the 12-year limits proposed above.

This addresses pros like renewal and anti-corruption while mitigating cons through sufficient tenure for expertise, as recommended in studies from nonpartisan sources like Pew and academic reviews. Alternatives like shorter limits (e.g., 8 years) amplify expertise loss, while no limits perpetuate incumbency issues seen in low turnover rates (under 10% voluntary).

To enhance effectiveness, pair with reforms like campaign finance limits or ethics rules, but term limits alone provide a structural fix. Ratification is challenging‚Äîover 200 proposals since 1789 have failed‚Äîbut public support (80%+) and state-level successes suggest viability via a convention of states under Article V. 

This approach honors the founders' intent for a dynamic republic without undermining democratic principles.

LACSON: NEXT BLUE RIBBON HEARING ON NOV. 14; 'VERY IMPORTANT WITNESS' TO BE INVITED

Senate President Pro Tempore Ping Lacson said that if he is reelected as chairman of the Senate Blue Ribbon Committee when the Senate resumes session on November 10, the panel's next hearing on anomalous flood control projects will be held on November 14.

Lacson said a "very important witness" will be invited to the hearing to help expedite the filing of airtight cases against certain politicians, Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) officials, and erring contractors.

He added that retired T/Sgt. Orly Guteza will also be invited to appear before the committee.

"If elected again as Blue Ribbon chairman on Nov 10, our hearing will resume on Nov 14. To help speed up the filing of airtight cases against some politicians, DPWH officials and errant contractors, we will invite among others, a 'very important witness' and retired T/Sgt Orly Guteza to shed more light on his 'sinumpaang salaysay,'" Lacson said in a post on X.

Guteza was the witness presented by Senate Deputy Minority Leader Rodante Marcoleta during the panel's September 25 hearing. Marcoleta said Guteza was referred to him by former Rep. Michael Defensor.

In his testimony, Guteza claimed he had delivered suitcases of cash‚Äîcodenamed "basura" (trash)‚Äîto the homes of former Ako Bicol Party-list Rep. Elizaldy Co and former House Speaker Martin Romualdez. Romualdez has since denied the allegations.

Lacson said the Blue Ribbon Committee left the investigation into the possible violation of Guteza's notarized affidavit to the Executive Judge of the Manila Regional Trial Court, after Atty. Petchie Rose Espera denied notarizing, signing, or participating in the preparation of Guteza's affidavit.

Lacson also confirmed that he has discussed with Senate President Vicente ‚ÄúTito‚Äù Sotto III the possibility of being reinstated as Blue Ribbon Committee chair‚Äîa post he vacated on October 6 following expressions of "disappointment" from some members of the majority bloc over his handling of the hearings. Several senators have since voiced their support for his return.

The senator maintained that he will continue to uphold impartiality in leading the investigation.

"I will maintain a blindfold mentality, meaning I will be impartial and go where the evidence leads," Lacson said.

@415552172609181 @403780272519270 Procurement lags in DPWH projects arise from extended bureaucratic timelines between feasibility studies, bidding invitations, and contract awards, which can stretch 6-12 months or longer due to reviews and disputes. These delays decouple estimates from real-time market rates, allowing inflation or supply shocks to erode purchasing power. For example, if steel prices rise 10-15% during the lag‚Äîas seen in 2024 import surges‚Äîactual procurement costs exceed budgets, prompting contractors to inflate bids for risk coverage and amplifying overpricing by 20-30%.

The Bureau of Internal Revenue (@984416394525436) may fall short of its 2025 tax collection goal after corruption scandals involving flood control projects disrupted its performance.

Department of Finance (@655837896366129) Undersecretary Charlito Martin R. Mendoza confirmed that the BIR has been hit harder than the Bureau of Customs (@638808770615574) by the issue, dragging down what had been a promising start to the year. Mendoza said the agency was on pace to meet its targets before the controversy slowed down collections.

‚ÄúFor the first half of the year, we were on track to meet the BIR‚Äôs collection target. Then there was a bit of a slowdown,‚Äù Mendoza said during the 4th SGV Tax Symposium on October 23.

From January to September, total government revenue reached ‚Ç±3.37 trillion, an 8.6 percent increase from ‚Ç±2.81 trillion in the same period last year. The BIR collected ‚Ç±2.32 trillion, up 10.9 percent from ‚Ç±2.09 trillion in 2024, covering 72.1 percent of its ‚Ç±3.22-trillion goal.

Corporate and personal income taxes, value-added tax (VAT), tobacco excise tax, and the percentage tax on financial institutions drove the BIR‚Äôs collections. Meanwhile, the BOC recorded ‚Ç±701.7 billion, up 1.6 percent from last year‚Äôs ‚Ç±690.7 billion, representing 73.2 percent of its ‚Ç±958.7-billion target.

Despite the growth, Mendoza admitted the government might miss its ‚Ç±4.21-trillion tax revenue target. However, the total ‚Ç±4.52-trillion goal could still be within reach through non-tax revenues. These, however, plunged 34.7 percent to ‚Ç±314.1 billion due to the absence of last year‚Äôs one-time remittances.

Mendoza said reforms are being rolled out to address the slowdown and restore confidence within the bureau. He remains hopeful that collection performance will recover by the last quarter.

The government aims for total revenues equivalent to 15.9 percent of gross domestic product (GDP) in 2025, but for the BIR, the challenge is clear‚Äîregain credibility, clean up internal systems, and prove it can still deliver despite the corruption cloud hanging over it.

The public could have something significant to look forward to once Sen. Panfilo Lacson is re-elected Blue Ribbon Committee chair and resumes the flood control project hearings.

A Nation Held Hostage by Corruption: A Call to Inner Strength

We are living in a time when corruption feels invincible‚Äîtoo entrenched, too protected, too shameless. From ghost flood control projects to the Napoles scandal, from two presidential impeachments to the betrayal of EDSA‚Äôs promise, we have seen it all. We ousted a dictator, only to welcome his son and witness the worst corruption in Philippine history.

Today, our Congress, Senate, and Executive branch are riddled with impunity. Our judiciary moves at a glacial pace. The powerful protect their own. The corrupt are not punished‚Äîthey are recycled, defended, and even celebrated.

It is tempting to say: Wala nang pag-asa.
That we are wasting our time.
That justice will never come.

But in the face of this despair, we must choose a different kind of resistance‚Äînot loud, not violent, but enduring.

Let us be calm. Let us stay strong.

Let us protect what we still have: our health, our families, our work, our simple joys. Let us raise children who know the difference between brilliance and integrity. Let us honor the quiet heroes‚Äînurses, teachers, farmers, and honest workers‚Äîwho build this country from the ground up.

We may not see the end of corruption in our lifetime. But we can live lives that reject it. We can build communities that resist it. We can speak truths that expose it.

And we can pray‚Äînot just for miracles, but for the strength to endure, the wisdom to discern, and the courage to keep going.

The Filipino people are not weak. We are wounded, yes‚Äîbut we are still standing.

And that, in itself, is a form of victory.

#RelentlessForChange

Senate Hearing on ICI‚Äôs Independence

Senator Rodante Marcoleta on Friday questioned the supposed independence of the Independent Commission for Infrastructure (ICI) after it was revealed that the body is currently borrowing prosecutors from the Department of Justice (DOJ) to help draft and review evidence.

During a hearing, DOJ Officer-in-Charge Secretary Fredderick Vida confirmed that the ICI has requested assistance from the department due to limited manpower. Marcoleta, however, stressed that an independent commission should be able to operate and gather information on its own.

‚ÄúKapag independent, gagawin niya ng sarili niya. Tingnan mo yung creation niya, it should be independent. Sa pangalan pa lang nga lang eh Independent Commission for Infrastructure,‚Äù the senator said.

Marcoleta also raised concerns over the ICI‚Äôs authority to seek information from the House of Representatives, the Senate, the Office of the Ombudsman, and other agencies. He warned that such powers may blur institutional boundaries and weaken systems of checks and balances if not properly handled.

‚ÄúPaano kang independent, ang dami mong kinakasangkapan? Hingi ka nang hingi. You should obtain the information by yourself all alone. Yun ang independent,‚Äù Marcoleta added.

In response, Vida maintained a respectful stance and did not directly contest the senator‚Äôs assertions.

‚ÄúWe submit to your wisdom, your honor,‚Äù he told the panel.

2. DPWH filed graft and malversation complaints (through falsification of public documents) over allegedly paid-for but unfinished or substandard flood-control projects in La Union and Davao Occidental.

The complaints were lodged against 22 DPWH officials and two contractors, Silverwolves Construction Corp. and St. Timothy Corp. [2]

3. Rep. Eric Yap was named a ‚Äúperson of interest‚Äù in connection with these projects.

Is it coincidence that these allocations overlap with Eric Yap‚Äôs tenure as Appropriations Chair (2020‚Äì2022)?

SA KULUNGAN NA SILA MAGPA-PASKO'

Posibleng sa kulungan na mag-Pasko ang ilang akusadong sangkot sa flood control scam, ayon kay Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) Sec. Vince Dizon sa isang panayam sa radyo nitong Biyernes, Oct. 24.

Maaaring kabilang daw dito sina dating DPWH-Bulacan district engineers Henry Alcantara, Brice Hernandez at Jaypee Mendoza gayundin ang contractor ng St. Timothy Corp. na si Sarah Discaya.

Kabilang sila sa unang batch ng DPWH officials at contractors na inireklamo ng ahensya para sa paglabag sa Anti-Graft and Corrupt Practices Act, Government Procurement Reform Act, at malversation of public funds sa tanggapan ng Ombudsman noong Setyembre.

The Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) has filed formal complaints against eight contractor-licensees involved in the flood control projects corruption scandal.

In a statement, the DTI said, through the exercise of its regulatory authority under Executive Order No. 913 (series of 1983) and other relevant trade and industry laws, it has filed complaints against contractors for possible violations of construction industry regulations due to their reported involvement in irregular flood control projects.

The contractors who are the subject of the complaints are eight of the top 15 contractors that cornered 20% of P545-billion worth of flood control contracts, as disclosed by President Ferdinand ‚ÄúBongbong‚Äù Marcos Jr. in August.

CAYETANO WARNS OF 'SYSTEMATIC ATTACK' AGAINST SENATE

Senate Minority Leader Alan Peter Cayetano on Thursday warned of what he described as a ‚Äúsystematic attack‚Äù against the Senate, as several lawmakers face controversies amid ongoing investigations into the flood control scandal.

"May systematic na attack sa Senate," Cayetano told reporters, noting that the recent wave of allegations appears aimed at discrediting the institution. "Makikita n'yo ngayon in context ng flood control na talagang y'ung iba sa amin ay target talaga... Dinidistract tayo eh. Napapainan tayo nang husto."

When asked who might be behind the supposed attacks, Cayetano said it could be "a group of people" rather than a single mastermind.

"We have some people in our minds, but we'd rather the evidence speak for it," he said.

The senator recalled last year's people's initiative campaign, which he claimed sought to "abolish the Senate." He believes it was part of a broader scheme by the same masterminds to advance their corrupt plans.

"We all know na habang ginagawa itong People's Initiative, binubuo pala itong scam na ito, hindi lang sa flood control ‚Äî paisa-isa lumalabas," Cayetano said.

The campaign, which aimed to amend the 1987 Constitution by making the House and Senate vote jointly on constitutional amendments, was heavily criticized by senators who warned that it would weaken the system of checks and balances.

Cayetano called on Senate President Tito Sotto to defend the institution from political attacks.

"Kung nangyari ito kay Risa Hontiveros o nangyari ito kay Ping Lacson, kahit nasa Minority ako, tatayuan ko ito. Bakit? May systematic na attack sa Senate," he said.

He also urged the Senate Blue Ribbon Committee to remain focused on identifying those behind the flood control scam.

"Eyes on the ball tayo... Dapat administration at opposition, nagkakaisa na ang mastermind ay makasuhan, makulong, ang pera mabalik, at mabago ang sistema," Cayetano said.

Muling nagsama-sama ang iba‚Äôt ibang grupo sa EDSA Shrine ngayong Biyernes, Oct. 24, 2025, upang ipanawagan ang pananagutan ng mga sangkot sa mga maanomalyang ghost flood control project.

Reps Move to Curb President's Power to Sack EFCC Chairman

The House of Representatives has advanced a landmark bill aimed at strengthening the independence of the Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC) by making it more difficult for a sitting President to unilaterally remove its Chairman.

The bill, which has passed a second reading, is sponsored by Hon. Yusuf Adamu Gagdi (APC, Plateau). It seeks to amend the EFCC (Establishment) Act of 2004 to insulate the anti-graft agency from political influence and align its operations with global best practices.

A key provision of the proposed legislation is to change the procedure for removing the EFCC Chairman. Currently, the President can dismiss the chairman at his discretion for reasons such as misconduct or inability to perform the functions of the office.

The new bill proposes that such a removal would require the approval of a two-thirds majority of both the Senate and the House of Representatives.

In his lead debate during Thursday's plenary, Hon. Gagdi argued that the amendment is necessary to modernize the EFCC's legal framework to effectively combat evolving financial crimes.

He stated that since the Act was enacted in 2004, the nature of financial crime has expanded dramatically to include cybercrime, cryptocurrency manipulation, and terrorism financing, which are not adequately addressed by the current law.

‚ÄúFurthermore, the existing Act does not provide sufficient guarantees for the independence of the Commission, exposing it to external influence and political interference,‚Äù the lawmaker stated.

Gagdi emphasized that the proposed reforms are designed to restore public confidence, enhance transparency, and ensure the EFCC operates as a professional and independent body.

‚ÄúThis amendment will not only ensure Nigeria‚Äôs global reputation but also promote good governance, economic stability, and public confidence in the fight against corruption,‚Äù he added.

The bill has been referred to the relevant House committee for further legislative action.

House of Representatives National Assembly Order Paper for Wednesday, October 22, 2025

The House of Representatives is pleased to announce the release of the Order Paper for legislative proceedings at the Green Chamber today, in furtherance of its commitment to transparency, legislative efficiency and institutional accountability.

Today's plenary will feature the presentation of key reports, the consideration of several significant bills for second and third readings, and the deliberation of motions addressing pressing national issues. The legislative day‚Äôs agenda reflects the House‚Äôs continued dedication to strengthening governance, reforming key institutions, and safeguarding citizens‚Äô welfare.

*Highlights of Today‚Äôs Agenda*

* *Reports for Presentation:*
  1. Committee on Rules and Business ‚Äì Report on the further review of the Standing Orders of the House of Representatives (Eleventh Edition).
  2. Committee on Basic Education and Services ‚Äì Report on the amendment to the Compulsory, Free and Universal Basic Education Act, Cap. N4, Laws of the Federation of Nigeria, 2004.

* *Bills for Third Reading:*
  1. Alvan Ikoku Federal University of Education, Owerri, Imo State (Establishment) Bill.
  2. Maitama Sule Federal University of Education, Kano, Kano State (Establishment) Bill.
  3. Federal University of Education, Zaria, Kaduna State (Establishment) Bill.
  4. Federal University of Technology, Kaduna (Establishment) Bill.
  5. Federal University, Biu, Borno State (Establishment) Bill.

* *Bills for Second Reading:*
  1. Constitution Alteration Bill to clarify taxation powers among the three tiers of government.
  2. Constitution Alteration Bill to prohibit presidential and gubernatorial pardons for corruption-related offences.
  3. Raw Materials Research and Development Council (Amendment) Bill.
  4. Agricultural Research Council (Amendment) Bill for the establishment of the Federal College of Agriculture and Technology, Opialu‚ÄìAjapo, Benue State.
  5. Federal Medical Centre, Port Harcourt (Establishment) Bill.
  6. Tertiary Education Trust Fund (Amendment) Bill to include private tertiary institutions.
  7. Bureau for Insurance of Government Assets (Establishment) Bill.
  8. Department of State Services Security Trust Fund (Establishment) Bill.

* *Motions for Deliberation:*
  1. Motion to investigate the alleged use of harmful chemicals in frozen food preservation in Nigeria ‚Äì Rep. Chike Okafor.
  2. Motion to address the backlog and ease the issuance of driver‚Äôs licences in Nigeria ‚Äì Rep. Felix Uche Nwaeke.

* *Reports for Consideration:*
  The House will also consider several reports from the Committees on Rules and Business, and Agricultural Colleges and Institutions, including bills to establish or amend research and training institutions across various states of the federation.

Committee meetings are also scheduled for the Committees on Rules and Business, Public Petitions, and Ethics and Privileges later in the day.

HINDI NA IPINIPILIT MAGING STATE WITNESS?

Hindi na umano ipinipilit ni dating Bulacan 1st District assistant engineer Brice Hernandez na maging state witness kaugnay ng imbestigasyon sa flood control project anomalies, ayon kay Ombudsman Boying Remulla.

Sinabi 'yan ni Remulla matapos ipatawag ng Office of the Ombudsman sina Hernandez at Henry Alcantara para sa kanilang fact-finding investigation.

Kinokonsidera na lang umano si Hernandez bilang "cooperative witness." Paliwanag ni Remulla, batid ni Hernandez na mahirap magbigay ng "blanket immunity" sa kanila lalo na sa isyu ng flood control.

"Open shot case 'yan, eh. Whether or not they cooperate, mako-convict naman sila talaga diyan, 'di ba? Hindi mo naman kailangan [ng] state witness doon kung tutuusin," aniya. I via Camille Samonte

Sa kanyang talumpati sa ika-124 na anibersaryo ng Philippine Coast Guard (PCG) na ginanap sa Port Area, Manila, noong Huwebes, Oktubre 23, labis ang pasasalamat ni Pangulong Ferdinand R. KAYA BA HINDI PA TUKOY ANG ADDRESS NI ZALDY CO? ‚Äî DOJ: WALA PANG TASK FORCE NA NAGHAHANAP

Tila lumilinaw na ang dahilan kung bakit hindi pa matukoy ng Independent Commission for Infrastructure (ICI) ang kasalukuyang address ni dating Ako Bicol Party-list Representative Zaldy Co ‚Äî wala pa palang itinalagang task force na naghahanap sa kanya, ayon sa Department of Justice (DOJ).

Sa panayam ng DZRH Balansyado nitong Huwebes, Oktubre 23, kinumpirma ni DOJ Spokesperson Atty. Polo Martinez na wala pang opisyal na grupo mula sa pamahalaan na inatasang maghanap kay Co, na una nang naiulat na nasa Spain.

‚ÄúAs of now, wala pang task force na naghahanap kay Zaldy Co. As far as we‚Äôre concerned, that is a law enforcement mandate. Ang law enforcement ang may papel na para maghanap kay Zaldy Co,‚Äù pahayag ni Martinez.

Paliwanag pa ni Martinez, hindi saklaw ng DOJ ang mismong paghahanap sa dating kongresista. Ang mandato umano ng kagawaran ay mag-prosecute ng mga kaso matapos ang imbestigasyon ng law enforcement agencies.

‚ÄúAng DOJ ang tungkulin po niya ay mag-prosecute ng mga krimen following the investigation conducted by law enforcement,‚Äù dagdag pa ng tagapagsalita.

Kaugnay nito, bagama‚Äôt patuloy ang imbestigasyon ng Bureau of Immigration (BI), sinabi ni Martinez na hindi pa rin sapat ang impormasyon para maglabas ng opisyal na pahayag ang DOJ hinggil sa lokasyon ni Co.

Ang pahayag ng DOJ ay kasunod ng ulat ng ICI na inaalam pa ang address ni Zaldy Co upang mapadalhan ito ng ikalawang subpoena, matapos siyang hindi sumipot sa pagdinig ng komisyon ukol sa flood control anomalies.

Cash is King: Ex-DPWH Usec Bernardo‚Äôs Billion-Peso Flood Scam Exposed

Habang lubog sa baha ang bansa, si dating DPWH Undersecretary Roberto R. Bernardo naman, lubog sa cash.

Ayon sa Anti-Money Laundering Council (AMLC), iniwasan daw ni Bernardo ang mga bangko para maitago ang bilyon-bilyong kickback galing umano sa flood-control projects ng DPWH. 

Ang twist? Nang tumaas ang pera, biglang ‚Äúnatuyo‚Äù ang bank records niya.

Ayon sa mga dokumentong isinapubliko ng AMLC, lumalabas na mula 2003 hanggang 2025, naging ‚Äúcash-based‚Äù ang lahat ng galaw ni Bernardo ‚Äî deposits, withdrawals, pati checks ‚Äî para walang papel na ebidensiya.

üëâ 2003‚Äì2013: Malakas ang galaw ng pera habang nasa Region IV-A pa siya.
üëâ 2020‚Äì2022: Biglang tigil sa bangko kahit na-promote na sa Undersecretary.
üëâ 2025: Bago pa man ang imbestigasyon, nag-withdraw ng malalaki ‚Äî halatang inunahan ang freeze order.

Ayon sa AMLC, malinaw ang pattern ‚Äî ‚Äúconsistent with money laundering.‚Äù May 39 bank accounts sa 10 bangko, 59 properties sa Bulacan, at insurance policies sa pangalan ng asawa niyang si Sunshine Miguel Bernardo.

Hindi lang ‚Äòyan ‚Äî ayon sa whistleblower na si Henry Alcantara, district engineer ng Bulacan, umabot sa ‚Ç±6.91 bilyon ang project funds na idinaan kay Bernardo, at ‚Ç±5 bilyon dito ay puro ghost projects.

Ang ‚Äúremittance‚Äù? Sa Diamond Hotel parking lot daw, kung saan may ‚Äúsuite‚Äù si Bernardo.

At ayon kay Alcantara, may bahagi pa raw napunta kina Sen. Chiz Escudero, Bong Revilla, Nancy Binay, at DepEd Usec Trygve Olaivar (umano‚Äôy para kay Executive Sec. Lucas Bersamin).

Matapos mabuko, agad siyang nag-retire noong August 15, ilang linggo lang matapos ang ‚Äúmahiya naman kayo‚Äù speech ni PBBM tungkol sa flood-control corruption.

Ngayon, naka-freeze na ang assets niya, at naghahanda ng kaso ang NBI, DPWH, at Ombudsman.

@893010964144557 @141771773603661 While competitive bidding aims for efficiency, substandard materials often stem from lax enforcement and corruption in inspections rather than bids alone. Philippine DPWH requires material testing and penalties, yet gaps in monitoring allow shortcuts regardless of bidder rank. Strengthening independent audits and tech like blockchain for transparency would curb savings-pocketing without scrapping the lowest-bid rule, which has delivered value in many projects.

@893010964144557 @141771773603661 CLTG Builders, named after Senator Bong Go's initials (Christopher Lawrence Tesoro Go), is a construction firm owned by his father that has won multiple DPWH contracts, including joint ventures with St. Gerrard Construction for Davao infrastructure projects worth over P300 million since 2016. Recent probes by DPWH and the Ombudsman examine its partnerships amid flood control controversies, but investigations focus on procedural links rather than proven corruption. Facts show standard bidding processes; media narratives often amplify political angles without conclusive evidence of cronyism.

PACC‚Äôs Camiguin Flip-Flop Exposes a Deeper Rot

How do you go from ‚Äú‚Ç±745.8 million worth of abandoned and defective projects‚Äù to ‚Äúno ghost projects, just right-of-way issues‚Äù in five days flat? If you are the Philippine Anti-Corruption Czar (PACC), apparently, it‚Äôs just another week on the job.

On October 15, the agency thundered about collusion, corruption, and shoddy materials. They demanded immediate national action, painting a damning picture of Camiguin‚Äôs infrastructure program as a monument to waste. Their own words: abandoned, prematurely terminated, substandard.

But by October 20, the same office struck a different tune. Suddenly, there were no ghost projects at all ‚Äî only delays, caused by routine right-of-way issues. The rhetoric shifted from systemic failure to mundane inconvenience. The corruption crisis vanished into a paperwork problem.

This isn‚Äôt just a messaging slip. It‚Äôs a credibility collapse. If PACC can swing from sounding the alarm to waving it off in less than a week, why should the public trust any of their findings? Did they uncover collusion, or did they overstate? Did pressure from political patrons twist the narrative?

Infrastructure failures don‚Äôt change overnight, but press releases do. What Camiguin residents are left with is a PACC that looks less like a watchdog and more like a weathervane ‚Äî spinning whichever way the power gusts blow. And that is the real scandal: not just defective bridges, but a defective anti-corruption body, wobbling on its own foundations.

Because if truth can be flipped on and off like a switch, then the rot isn‚Äôt just in Camiguin‚Äôs concrete. It‚Äôs in the institutions sworn to protect us from it.

DAWIT DIN SA FLOOD CONTROL ANOMALIES?

Itinuturing ni Ombudsman Boying Remulla si Benguet Rep. Eric Yap bilang person of interest sa umano'y maanomalyang flood control project sa La Union.

Sa isang press briefing, sinabi ni Remulla na beneficial owner si Rep. Eric ng Silverwolves Construction Corporation, ang contractor sa proyekto. Titingnan ng Ombudsman kung may conflict of interest noong naging chairperson ng House Committee on Appropriations si Rep. Eric.

Ibinahagi rin ng Ombudsman ang ulat ng Anti-Money Laundering Council (AMLC) kaugnay ng umano'y paglipat ng mga Discaya ng pera sa account ng kapatid ni Rep. Eric na si ACT-CIS Rep. Edvic Yap at Bulacan 6th District Rep. Salvador Pleyto.

Wala pang reaksyon ang mga kongresista sa alegasyon.

BAM TO PBBM: CERTIFY CAP ACT AS URGENT

Sen. Bam Aquino has urged President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. to certify as urgent the Classroom-Building Acceleration Program (CAP) Act as a solution to the country's classroom backlog.

Aquino, author of Senate Bill No. 121 or the CAP Act, said the Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) cannot address the problem alone, citing its recent report that only 22 out of its 1,700 target classrooms for 2025 have been completed so far.

"Lahat tayo nagulat nung nalaman natin na bente dos lang ang classrooms na ginawa ng DPWH ngayong taon. Ang backlog natin 145,000 pataas kaya iyong 22 na paggawa ng DPWH, hindi po talaga iyan katanggap-tanggap," said Aquino, chairperson of the Senate Committee on Basic Education.

While Senate Bill No. 121 has already been identified as one of the administration's priority measures in the 20th Congress, Aquino said President Marcos should take the next step by certifying the bill as urgent to ensure its swift passage.

"Ang panawagan namin sa Classroom Acceleration Program Bill ay ibigay ito sa mga LGU. Natutuwa kami na sa araw na ito, sinang-ayunan tayo ng Presidente. We're hoping na dahil nag-a-agree na po tayo dito, ise-certify po niya na urgent ang Classroom Acceleration Program para sabay-sabay po tayong gagawa ng mga classroom para sa ating mga kabataan," he added.

If passed into law, Aquino said Senate Bill No. 121 will complement the President's directive to channel funds directly to local government units (LGUs) to help expedite the construction of much-needed classrooms.

The senator's proposed measure seeks to decentralize classroom construction by expanding the mandate beyond the DPWH to include LGUs and non-government organizations (NGOs) with a proven track record.

Under the bill, LGUs and NGOs may build classrooms within their jurisdictions in compliance with the Department of Education's standards and guidelines.

"Mahalaga po na ilagay na lang natin iyong responsibilidad ng paggawa ng classroom sa mga grupo at tao na kaya talagang gawin ito sa madaliang panahon at sa tamang presyo," Aquino explained.

"Mga local government unit, mga NGO na may track record, sabay-sabay po iyan para ma-address natin iyong napakalaking problema po natin sa edukasyon," he added.

During the Senate hearing on the DPWH budget, Public Works Secretary Vince Dizon expressed full support for Aquino's proposal, saying the agency is open to partnerships that will help speed up the construction of much-needed classrooms nationwide.

"We are in full support of this measure, especially now na dalawampu't dalawa pa lang ang nagagawa ng departamento ngayong taon. Kailangan po talaga natin ang tulong," Dizon said.

"At this rate, it's virtually impossible na magawa ng DPWH itong kailangan nating mga classrooms," he admitted.

CHIZ: PEOPLE, LGUs MUST HAVE A SAY IN INFRA PROJECTS

Sen. Chiz Escudero said local government units (LGUs) and communities should have a decisive role in determining infrastructure projects to be implemented in their areas, especially in the upcoming 2026 General Appropriations Act (GAA) and future budgets.

"Sa dami ng mga lumitaw na problema sa mga government infrastructure projects kabilang na ang mga substandard at 'ghost' flood control projects, kailangan talaga na gumawa ng makabuluhan na solusyon para hindi na nasasayang ang pera ng bayan sa katiwalian," Escudero said.

The senator pointed out that many irregularities in infrastructure funding stem from arbitrary insertions made by legislators in coordination with Executive officials‚Äîprojects that never underwent scrutiny or feasibility evaluation.

"This is the very issue being raised with regard to insertions in the budget," Escudero said, noting that several of these "ghost projects" were discovered in past GAAs and confirmed by Commission on Audit findings.

To address this, Escudero filed the proposed Grassroots Infrastructure Planning and Budgeting Act, which requires that all infrastructure projects be endorsed first by the Regional Development Council (RDC) and the Provincial, City, or Municipal Development Councils, as well as their respective Sanggunian, before being included in the National Expenditure Program (NEP) submitted by the President to Congress.

"Doon pa lang sa NEP dapat wala ng nakakalusot na proyekto na hindi kailangan ng isang probinsya o bayan," he said. "Mas lalo pang mahalaga ang pag-endorso ng ating mga local government units sa mga proyekto na hinahabol ng mga mambabatas bilang amendment na kadalasan ay naipapasok sa GAA o ang pinal na bersyon ng budget na pinirmahan na ng Pangulo bilang batas."

Under the bill, the RDC's or local councils' endorsement will be a condition sine qua non for including any infrastructure project in the GAA or releasing funds for its implementation.

"Pag walang endorsement o approval ng RDC, walang pera na ilalabas ang DBM para sa anumang proyekto," Escudero emphasized.

The senator urged Congress to prioritize the bill's passage, saying it would help prevent budget abuses and strengthen reforms in the government's infrastructure planning and allocation process.

HAPPENING NOW: President Ferdinand R. Marcos Jr. leads the 124th anniversary of the Philippine Coast Guard (PCG) at Pier 15, South Harbor in Port Area, City of Manila on Thursday (Oct. 23, 2025). 

PBBM now delivering his message: Alam na alam kong hindi madali ang inyong trabaho, kita naman sa lahat ng inyong ginagawa.

PBBM: In the West Philippine Sea, you are our first responders, ensuring the safety, dignity and livelihood of our fisherfolk.

PBBM: This is the PCG that works quietly and effectively. In these times when our seas face greater challenges, you remain steadfast, proving that courage knows no tides and that service knows no bounds.

PBBM: You stand as guardians of safety and of stability, and in return, I assure you that this government is solidly behind. 

PBBM: The PCG is one of the government agencies that restores my faith in the dedication of the workers in government.

PBBM: When I see the PCG in action, I see what the best of gov‚Äôt can look like. That is discipline with integrity, with excellence, working as one. 

PBBM: I know that these are difficult times that we live in. Our people's trust in government has been shaken. We cannot deny that, but I am certain that trust can be regained if we remain transparent and true to our mission.

PBBM: Whenever our people see you during rescue missions or in your day to day patrols, what they see is that the gov‚Äôt is still working diligently and is worthy of their trust.

PBBM: Truly, the sea offers no defined path. It shifts & tests your steadiness, but I believe it also rewards those who stay the course and remain true to their mission. For each time you sail, you remind the world that the Philippines will always protect what is ours.| Darryl John Esguerra

PROTEKTADO ANG MGA DOKUMENTO

Nilinaw ni Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) Sec. Vince Dizon na protektado ang lahat ng dokumentong may kinalaman sa imbestigasyon sa flood control anomalies sa central office ng kagawaran sa Maynila.

Giit ng kalihim, walang magiging epekto sa imbestigasyon ang nangyaring sunog sa DPWH-Bureau of Research Standards building. May digital backup din ang mga dokumentong nadamay sa sunog.

"We have gotten all (flood control documents) from 2022 to 2025, and we are now receiving earlier years, but they are now all here, in the Central Office, protected here," sabi ni Dizon.

The Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) has clarified earlier reports regarding the fire that broke out at one of its facilities in Quezon City, confirming that it was the Bureau of Research and Standards (BRS) building ‚Äî not the Region 4B office ‚Äî that was affected. https://t.co/UDpkqT1sKH

BULACAN FLOOD CONTROL: CALUMPIT RESIDENTS, 5 BUWANG LUBOG SA BAHA

Halos limang buwan nang lubog sa baha ang Barangay San Miguel, Calumpit, Bulacan, dahilan para lumikas ang mga residente kaugnay sa maanomalyang flood control projects sa lugar.

Ngayong Huwebes, Oktubre 23, ayon sa isang 70-anyos na residente, simula pa noong Hulyo ay nakikitira na siya sa kanyang kapatid matapos magdulot ng malawakang pagbaha ang malalakas na ulan bunsod ng bagyong ‚ÄúCrising.‚Äù

Samantala, isang 87-anyos na residente, kasama ang kanyang pamilya, ang pansamantalang nakikituloy sa loob ng isang vulcanizing shop.

Batay sa ulat, kasalukuyan namang nananatili sa mga evacuation center ang 18 pang pamilya.

Dahil dito, apektado rin ang kabuhayan ng mga residente dahil tinatayang 70 porsyento ng mga bahay ang lubog pa rin sa baha.

Giit naman ng mga residente, ito ang pinakamahabang panahon na lubog sa baha ang kanilang barangay na malapit sa Pampanga River, dahilan upang lalo pang tumaas ang tubig tuwing high tide.

The Department of Justice (@712738068197135) confirmed that no assets of elected officials linked to the flood control anomalies have been frozen.

Justice Undersecretary Jesse Hermogenes Andres made the statement during the Senate sub-panel hearing on the proposed 2026 DOJ budget. Senator Rodante Marcoleta had asked if the agency had filed a request with the Anti-Money Laundering Council (AMLC) to freeze the assets of politicians allegedly involved in the issue.

Andres said he could provide the names of those whose assets were affected but clarified that the freeze orders only covered personnel from the Department of Public Works and Highways (@392192773701614). ‚ÄúI do not have copies of that [right now]. And if I may clarify, I think the freeze orders have not touched politicians. I mean, government officials like DPWH officials are already part of the freeze orders,‚Äù Andres said.

He reiterated that while DPWH officials‚Äô assets were included, no elected officials were covered. ‚ÄúGovernment officials, meaning DPWH officials ‚Äî yes. But elected officials, I do not,‚Äù he added.

Andres‚Äô statement contradicted an earlier claim made by former Justice Secretary and now Ombudsman @29666241887838. Remulla had previously said that the AMLC, acting on the recommendation of the National Bureau of Investigation (NBI), secured freeze orders from the Court of Appeals against the assets of Senators @453051177733422 and @24527930920607, and resigned Ako Bicol Rep. @763116735601112.

The clarification from the DOJ followed online reports claiming that the assets of some politicians had already been frozen. Andres maintained that these claims were inaccurate and that only DPWH personnel were included in the existing freeze orders.

Understanding the Rappler Report on Martin Romualdez‚Äôs U.S. Property Transfer

This Rappler headline can easily mislead readers‚Äîespecially those unfamiliar with U.S. business, financial, or real estate practices‚Äîinto thinking that a legal transaction involving former House Speaker Martin Romualdez is questionable. At first glance, transferring a ‚Ç±130-million (or dollar equivalent) Massachusetts property to a U.S. corporation for just $1 may sound scandalous. However, a closer look shows that such a transaction is neither unusual nor necessarily irregular under U.S. law. 

In the United States, it is common practice for property owners to transfer ownership of real estate from their personal name to a corporation or limited liability company (LLC) that they own or control. This is typically done through a legal instrument known as a quitclaim deed.

The ‚Äú$1 consideration‚Äù often seen in such deeds is merely a symbolic legal formality required to make the document valid‚Äîit does not reflect the actual market value of the property. This type of administrative transfer is often used for legitimate purposes such as:
---Estate planning or inheritance management
---Asset protection and liability limitation
---Adding or removing family members from a property title
---Moving property into a trust or business entity for organizational efficiency

These transfers are not considered ‚Äúsales‚Äù in the commercial sense. Similar practices also exist in the Philippines, where families and business owners sometimes move properties into corporations they own for easier management or to separate personal and corporate liability.

In this context, the legal mechanics of the transaction reported by Rappler appear to be consistent with standard U.S. real estate and corporate practices.

However, journalists are also justified in examining the broader context‚Äîespecially when public officials are involved. While a quitclaim deed transfer may be legal, questions about timing, transparency, and beneficial ownership are legitimate in the public interest. For example, the public has a right to know whether the property continues to appear accurately in a public official‚Äôs Statement of Assets, Liabilities, and Net Worth (SALN) after such a restructuring.

Rappler‚Äôs article reportedly noted that quitclaim deeds are legal and widely practiced, and included expert opinions to that effect. Still, the presentation may have emphasized the property‚Äôs market value compared to the $1 consideration, which could create an impression of irregularity even if none exists.

Ultimately, the transaction itself appears administrative rather than suspicious, and there is no evidence presented of concealment or illegality. But scrutiny of the financial dealings of public officials‚Äîno matter how routine those dealings may be‚Äîis part of ensuring transparency and maintaining public trust.

To avoid any future misinterpretation‚Äîespecially during periods of heightened public distrust, such as the ongoing flood control controversy‚ÄîRappler should make it a point to clearly and repeatedly emphasize the legality of any transaction it reports on. Doing so will help ensure that readers understand when a transaction is lawful and prevent the public from drawing the wrong conclusions based on headlines or context alone. Yesterday, while the Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) was being roasted in investigations over alleged billions in flood control anomalies, fate,  or perhaps engineering genius, to join the show.

At precisely the moment scrutiny was tightening, a computer in the DPWH office reportedly ‚Äúexploded‚Äù and triggered a third-alarm fire.

Now, according to real-world data, the chance of a computer in an office spontaneously bursting into flames is about one in several million per year, roughly equivalent to a stapler achieving sentience or a printer finally working on the first try.

And yet, the DPWH somehow beat the odds.

üñ•Ô∏è THE STATISTICAL MIRACLE OF THE YEAR

Let‚Äôs review the facts:
‚Ä¢The odds of a desktop computer catching fire: ‚âà1 in 5,000,000 per year.
‚Ä¢The odds of one exploding dramatically: essentially zero.
‚Ä¢The odds of that happening in an office under investigation for corruption: somewhere in the range of ‚ÄúAsk your nearest mathematician, they just fainted.‚Äù

If this were an insurance claim, actuaries would file it under ‚ÄúActs of God, or Guilty Conscience.‚Äù

üîç THE ‚ÄúCOMPUTER DID IT‚Äù DEFENSE

In an official statement, DPWH spokespeople insisted that the fire originated from a computer unit, not any ‚Äúsensitive documents.‚Äù
Ah yes, the timeless line: ‚ÄúThe evidence wasn‚Äôt destroyed; it simply got warm.‚Äù

The Ombudsman, however, isn‚Äôt buying it. He called the blaze ‚Äúdisturbing,‚Äù which is bureaucratic code for ‚ÄúAre you kidding me?‚Äù

One wonders:
If computers in government offices are now self-immolating, perhaps they‚Äôre simply protesting their working conditions ‚Äî or their user‚Äôs browsing history.

üî• A NEW SCIENCE: CORRUPTOLOGY OF SPONTANEOUS COMBUSTION

In the normal universe, overheating happens when dust blocks ventilation or a battery is punctured.
In the DPWH universe, however, corruption allegations appear to generate so much friction that entire PCs ignite out of shame.

Maybe that computer just couldn‚Äôt handle another Excel file labeled ‚ÄúFlood Control Project ‚Äì Confidential.‚Äù

The Bureau of Fire Protection and NBI are investigating, but honestly, they‚Äôll need both fire extinguishers and lie detectors for this one.

üßæ THE AFTERMATH: NOTHING TO SEE HERE

DPWH quickly assured the public that ‚Äúno flood control files were damaged.‚Äù
How reassuring. Fires, it seems, have developed the uncanny moral compass to burn only irrelevant items.

It‚Äôs the same miracle that often happens when warehouses full of ‚Äúnon-essential‚Äù customs documents go up in flames.
Coincidence, of course ‚Äî our national specialty.

üí£ THE EPILOGUE: WHEN CORRUPTION MEETS PHYSICS

If a typical office computer has a 0.00001% chance of exploding, and DPWH is caught in a billion-peso scandal, the probability of this fire being accidental is somewhere between a unicorn sighting and a guilt-ridden laptop committing arson in solidarity.

The whole nation watched smoke rise from Quezon City and thought, ‚ÄúThere goes another file backup.‚Äù

So here‚Äôs the lesson:
In the Philippines, justice is slow, accountability is rare, but combustion is curiously punctual.

A Nine-Year-Old Dismissal That Refuses to Die

Nearly a decade has passed since the Ombudsman found Senator Joel Villanueva guilty of funneling ‚Ç±10 million in pork barrel funds into ghost projects. In 2016, the Senate brushed it aside, saying only senators can police their own. Villanueva stayed, prospered, and the case was quietly buried.

Now, Ombudsman Jesus Crispin Remulla is digging up the old dismissal order and shoving it back onto the Senate‚Äôs desk. The question is simple: will the Senate finally enforce accountability, or will it once again prove that senators live in a republic of their own making?

The implications cut deeper than Villanueva‚Äôs seat. If the Ombudsman can‚Äôt touch a senator, then corruption cases against lawmakers are paper tigers‚Äîpress releases with no bite. But if this old ruling is suddenly enforced, it could redraw the lines of power and remind every lawmaker that dismissal orders don‚Äôt expire with time or convenience.

In a country where scandals often vanish in the fog of politics, this revival is either a turning point‚Äîor another reminder that justice in the Philippines has an expiration date, depending on who you are.

The investigation into the flood control scandal should not be a family witch hunt, a business leader said on Monday, urging President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. to let the investigators do their work and avoid any appearance of political interference.

Apa Ongpin, executive director of the Makati Business Club, told Bilyonaryo News Channel‚Äôs ‚ÄúAt The Forefront‚Äù program that it would be unfair and damaging for Leyte Rep. and former House Speaker Martin Romualdez to be implicated in the controversy without a ‚Äúfair and independent‚Äù investigation.

‚ÄúThat would not be a good outcome for us if he throws him under the bus. It has to be a fair and independent investigation, not at the instigation of Malaca√±ang,‚Äù Ongpin told BNC anchor Karen Jimeno.

‚ÄúThey sort of instruct the investigators. It cannot be. It has to be fair. If he‚Äôs really got some kind of liability, let that be exposed through proper process‚Ä¶ These people, the accused in this thing, all deserve due process,‚Äù he added.

Ongpin also rejected insinuations that the Office of the Ombudsman and the Independent Commission for Infrastructure (ICI) were taking orders from Malaca√±ang to target Romualdez.

‚ÄúThey better not be. They (ICI investigators) were appointed to be impartial and they were appointed to be apolitical. They shouldn‚Äôt be waiting for a go-signal from the President,‚Äù he said.

Romualdez was implicated in the scandal after a supposed former security consultant of resigned Ako Bicol Rep. Zaldy Co claimed that he had delivered suitcases filled with cash to his houses, an allegation he had vehemently denied.

Contractors Sarah and Curlee Discaya earlier claimed that Romualdez and other lawmakers had demanded 30-percent in kickbacks from flood control deals awarded to their construction firms.

Last month, Romualdez stepped down as Speaker of the House of Representatives to allow ‚Äúfull accountability and transparency‚Äù amid the controversies over the anomalous infrastructure projects.

Marcos had repeatedly vowed that no one, not even his family members or political allies, would be spared from the ongoing crackdown on those behind the irregularities in the government‚Äôs infrastructure projects.

CAYETANO WELCOMES LACSON'S RETURN AS BLUE RIBBON CHAIR, CALLS FOR UNITY AND INTEGRITY IN PROBE

Senate Minority Leader Alan Peter Cayetano on Wednesday expressed support for the reinstatement of Senate President Pro Tempore Ping Lacson as chair of the Senate Blue Ribbon Committee, emphasizing the need for cooperation, transparency, and integrity in the chamber‚Äôs investigations.

"As I've said, it's the majority's choice, and the minority respects that. We will continue to work with Senator Lacson in the spirit of cooperation and transparency ‚Äî because the stakes for our nation are too high for us not to work together," Cayetano said in a statement.

He stressed that the focus should not be on leadership changes but on ensuring a fair and unified approach to uncovering corruption and restoring public trust.

"The Blue Ribbon's power lies in its INTEGRITY ‚Äî in making sure that both our goals of uncovering the truth and the means to achieve them are beyond politics and personal agenda.," he said.

Cayetano underscored that while it is easier to use hearings for political gain, the Senate must take the "harder but more necessary path" of exposing corruption masterminds and pushing for systemic reforms.

"The Senate is at its best when it rises above partisanship and stands together for truth and accountability. That's the standard the Minority aims for ‚Äî that's the standard we should all aim for," he added.

During the Finance Committee Hearing on the proposed budget of the Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH), I emphasized the need for clear and equitable way to plan and distribute infrastructure budgets. I urged DPWH to move away from confusing method and use a simpler, more open process that meets community needs and treats every region fairly.

Some districts with fewer people and smaller land areas still get much larger budgets in both the National Expenditure Program (NEP) and General Appropriations Bill (GAB). This imbalance persists even in areas that are geographically more challenged and have greater identified infrastructure needs. Equity in infrastructure means understanding that districts have different starting points. It involves providing support that fits the specific challenges each area faces. I called for a detailed breakdown of each district's budget so Congress can review these gaps and support more logical, data-based planning. To help fix ongoing issues with overpricing, I suggested a temporary 25% cut to all DPWH line items while the agency reviews real costs.

I repeated how important it is to be transparent when carrying out projects. There should be public access to DPWH‚Äôs internal monitoring tools, so people can track progress and take part in oversight. These changes are needed to rebuild public trust and make sure infrastructure projects are accountable.

WALANG NASUNOG NA EBIDENSYA?

Tiniyak ng Independent Commission for Infrastructure (ICI) na walang anumang dokumentong may kaugnayan sa mga flood control projects ang naapektuhan sa naganap na sunog sa DPWH office sa Quezon City nitong Miyerkules, Oktubre 22.

‚ÄúAyon sa mga record ngayon, ang nasunog sa Quezon City ay walang kinalaman sa flood control projects.‚Äù
(‚ÄúAs per record now, the burning in Quezon City does not involve flood control projects.‚Äù)
‚Äî ICI Chairman Andres Reyes Jr.

Ang pahayag ay inilabas ni Retired Justice Andres Reyes Jr., chairman ng ICI, sa pagdinig ng Senate Committee on Justice and Human Rights kaugnay ng Senate Bill No. 1215 na naglalayong magtatag ng Independent People‚Äôs Commission (IPC).

Dagdag pa ni Reyes, bagaman walang flood control files na nasunog, kinakailangan pa ring tiyakin ang seguridad ng mga dokumento ng Commission on Audit (COA) dahil may posibilidad umanong may mga taong gustong sirain ang mga ito.

‚ÄúKailangan nating siguruhin ang lahat ng record ng COA‚Ä¶ alam ko kasing may mga kriminal na may tendensiyang sunugin ang opisina.‚Äù
(‚ÄúWe have to secure all records of the COA because‚Ä¶ I know that there‚Äôs a tendency for criminals to burn down the office.‚Äù)

Una na ring kinumpirma ng DPWH na walang mga dokumento na konektado sa imbestigasyon ng flood control anomalies ang nadamay sa apoy. Ang nasunog na gusali ay ang Bureau of Research and Standards (BRS) na responsable sa pananaliksik, pag-aaral, at pagbuo ng mga polisiya para sa mga proyektong pang-imprastraktura ng gobyerno.

Ang Bureau of Fire Protection (BFP) ay nakapagtala na ang sunog ay nagsimula bandang 12:39 p.m., umabot sa third alarm pagsapit ng 12:56 p.m., at tuluyang naapula bandang 1:34 p.m.

HINDI PA RAW TUKOY ANG KASALUKUYANG ADDRESS NI ZALDY CO ‚Äî ICI INAAALAM PA

Hindi pa rin tukoy ng Independent Commission for Infrastructure (ICI) ang kasalukuyang address ng resigned Ako Bicol Party-list Representative Zaldy Co, dahilan upang ipagpaliban muna ang pagpapadala ng ikalawang subpoena para sa kanya kaugnay ng imbestigasyon sa umano‚Äôy maanomalyang flood control projects.

Ayon kay ICI Executive Director at Spokesperson Atty. Brian Hosaka, inaalam pa ng komisyon ang tumpak na address ni Co upang matiyak na maipapadala ang subpoena alinsunod sa tamang proseso.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre looking at it. We reviewed our records and we just want to make sure that a subpoena should have been sent in accordance with our procedure. So we‚Äôre looking at sending another subpoena to him just to be sure that we covered everything,‚Äù ani Hosaka.

(‚ÄúTinitingnan namin ito. Sinusuri namin ang aming mga rekord upang masiguro na ang subpoena ay maipadala ayon sa tamang proseso. Kaya pinag-aaralan naming magpadala ng isa pa upang masiguro na nasaklaw namin ang lahat.‚Äù)

Si Co ay hindi nakadalo sa Oktubre 13 na pagdinig ng ICI, kung saan ipinatawag din si dating House Speaker Martin Romualdez upang magpaliwanag hinggil sa umano‚Äôy iregularidad sa flood control at proseso ng pag-apruba ng pondo. Batay sa pinakahuling impormasyon, si Co ay kasalukuyang nasa Spain, ngunit wala pang kumpirmadong lokal na address na maaring padalhan ng bagong subpoena.
