Rappler‚Äôs recent headline, ‚ÄúMartin Romualdez Transfers P130-M U.S. Property to Corporation For Just USD1‚Äù -- was clearly crafted to provoke outrage. What it leaves out, however, is far more important than what it says. The U.S. property in question was purchased in 1988, decades before Martin Romualdez entered public service. 

This crucial context was not only omitted from the headline but hidden behind a paywall, a deliberate move, perhaps, knowing most Filipinos won‚Äôt go past the headline before forming an opinion.

Romualdez has already addressed the issue directly. In his statement, he clarified:

‚ÄúThe U.S. property was purchased before I entered public service, has always been declared in my SALN, and will continue to be so. The arrangement was made solely for property management purposes, no concealment, no irregularity, and no violation of any law.‚Äù

This kind of transfer, turning a personally owned property into a corporate asset for a token amount, is a standard and legitimate practice among high-net-worth individuals. It‚Äôs a way to manage estate matters, simplify ownership, and protect assets through corporate structuring. Wealthy families worldwide do this to ensure smoother administration, particularly when properties are held overseas. It is not an attempt to hide wealth, but to organize it legally and transparently.

Critics tend to ignore one simple truth, Romualdez was already a wealthy man long before entering politics. Belonging to the well-established Romualdez clan, his affluence is both inherited and publicly declared. His assets have been consistently reported in his Statements of Assets, Liabilities, and Net Worth (SALN), the very document that assures transparency among public officials.

The real disservice here lies in the framing. Rappler‚Äôs headline implies wrongdoing without context, then places the full explanation behind a paid membership wall.

It‚Äôs a clever tactic, capitalize on outrage, monetize curiosity, and let misinformation spread freely. In an age where people read headlines more than full articles, this approach fuels half-truths and misjudgment.

In truth, there is no scandal here, only selective storytelling. 

Martin Romualdez‚Äôs statement stands clear, no concealment, no irregularity, and no violation of any law. The property transfer was a business formality, not a political controversy. What‚Äôs missing is not transparency from the former Speaker, but honesty in how the story is told.

The Department of Public Works and Highways (@392192773701614) has confirmed that no important documents related to the ongoing flood control investigation were lost in the fire that broke out earlier today at the Bureau of Research and Standards (BRS) building in Quezon City. However, the Independent Commission on Infrastructure (ICI) made a remark that perhaps 1% of documents related to flood control might have been involved in the incident.

Following this, the DPWH clarified in a statement that no documents related to the flood control investigation were affected. DPWH Bureau of Research and Standards Director IV, Juliana Vergara, also explained in an interview that the damaged documents were mainly reports related to the regular validation of materials, including calibration reports from various regions and district offices. She clarified, "Wala pong document pertaining to the issues na yung pong pinag uusapan ngayon na naapektuhan po dahil kami po ay nagko-contact ng research."

The DPWH assured the public that no employees were harmed during the fire, and the situation was quickly contained by firefighters. An investigation team has already been deployed to assess the damage and determine the full extent of the incident. They are also exploring measures to prevent similar events in the future.

The DPWH emphasized that the ongoing flood control investigation and other critical operations were not disrupted by the fire. The Bureau of Research and Standards, which handles research, testing, and policy development for public infrastructure projects, continues to operate despite the incident.

LOCAL UPDATE: A fire broke out at the Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) Bureau of Research and Standards (BRS) building in Barangay Pinyahan, Quezon City today, October 22.  

The fire reached third alarm before being declared under control at 1:34 PM and fully extinguished at 1:49 PM. No personnel were reported injured.  

According to initial findings, the blaze originated from the explosion of a computer unit inside the Materials Testing Division.  

In a statement, the DPWH said no documents related to the ongoing investigation into flood control anomalies were stored in the BRS building. The bureau, which is responsible for research and policy formulation for infrastructure projects, has launched an internal probe to determine the extent of damage and prevent similar incidents in the future.  

Photos by Tracy G. Rodriguez

The Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) is set to construct a two-lane detour road as a portion of the Bukidnon-Davao (BuDa) Road remains closed following a landslide on Saturday that disrupted travel for hundreds of motorists and commuters.

Quezon municipal information officer Forts Cabarde said the works, including the detour road construction and soil testing for rehabilitation, are expected to take around two months. The detour will be built near the damaged portion of the road.

As of now, the affected portion, with only one lane left, remains impassable to all types of vehicles and even pedestrians.

A makeshift trail located a few meters away in a hilly area is currently being used by individuals and motorcycle riders, but the steep terrain makes it difficult for those carrying goods or for persons with disabilities.

BOC to auction 13 luxury cars owned by Discaya couple on Nov. 15 ‚Äî worth up to ‚Ç±200M

Tuloy na ang public auction ng 13 smuggled luxury cars na pagmamay-ari umano ng kontrobersyal na contractor couple na sina Pacifico ‚ÄúCurlee‚Äù at Cezarah ‚ÄúSarah‚Äù Discaya.

Ayon sa Bureau of Customs (BOC), gaganapin ang auction sa Nobyembre 15, 2025.

Kinumpirma ni BOC Assistant Commissioner Atty. Vincent Maranilla na ibebenta sa publiko ang mga sasakyan matapos mabigong patunayan ng mag-asawang Discaya ang legalidad ng kanilang importation papers.

‚ÄúYung 13 luxury cars ng mag-asawang Discaya, meron kaming warrant of seizure and detention. Since hindi nila mapatunayan ang legal na pagbili at pagpasok ng mga ito sa bansa, ipa-aauction na namin sa Nobyembre 15,‚Äù ani Maranilla.

Batay sa imbestigasyon ng BOC, pitong sasakyan ang walang import entry records o certificates of payment, habang ang anim naman ay may dokumento pero peke o kulang sa bayad.

Tinatayang aabot sa ‚Ç±100 milyon hanggang ‚Ç±200 milyon ang posibleng halaga ng mga sasakyan sa auction. Ayon kay Maranilla, ang kikitain dito ay mapupunta sa mga priority projects ng gobyerno.

‚ÄúMakakaasa ang mga bibili na dadaan sa tamang proseso at may certificate na ito ay nabili sa auction ng BOC, kaya ligtas itong gamitin,‚Äù dagdag ng opisyal.

Here we go again with a headline that looks scandalous at first glance, pero kung babasahin mo ang buong article, puro assumptions at insinuations at wala namang proof ng ‚Äúscandal‚Äù or even ‚Äúirregularity.‚Äù

This Rappler headline about Martin Romualdez transferring a ‚Ç±130-million Massachusetts property to a U.S. corporation for just $1 sounds scandalous.

But based on my own experience living and doing business in the U.S., this is actually normal.

Those who have formed LLCs, S Corps, or C Corps in the States know that this kind of transaction is neither illegal nor unusual.

In the U.S., property owners often use a ‚Äúquitclaim deed‚Äù to transfer ownership from an individual to a corporation they own or control. 

The ‚Äú$1‚Äù is just a symbolic consideration required by law to make the restructuring valid. It has nothing to do with the property‚Äôs market value.

And you don‚Äôt have to be a politician or a multi-millionaire to do this. 

A quitclaim deed is commonly used by parents transferring property to children, or when adding or removing a spouse from a title after marriage or divorce. It‚Äôs also used to move a property into a trust, corporation, or LLC for inheritance or asset management.

In other words, it‚Äôs administrative, not a sale.

Syempre, kung hater ka lang na hindi naiintindihan ang asset management dahil wala kang properties or never ka pang nag-register ng corporation, grabe, corruption na agad! üòÇ

Hindi rin ito alien practice sa Pilipinas ha. Many Filipino families transfer properties to a corporation they own or control for better management and to limit personal liability.

The main reason is exactly that: to limit personal liability. A corporation kasi is treated as a separate legal entity, which means the owner‚Äôs personal assets can‚Äôt be used to pay the corporation‚Äôs debts or legal issues. 

So, kung common practice naman pala yan kahit sa Pilipinas, what‚Äôs the big deal?

What‚Äôs ironic is that Rappler‚Äôs own article admits quitclaim deeds are legal and widely practiced. They even quote U.S. lawyers confirming it‚Äôs legitimate for management and estate purposes.

What makes Rappler‚Äôs presentation misleading is its fixation on the property‚Äôs market value versus the $1 figure, which insinuates ‚Äúscandal,‚Äù ‚Äúirregularity,‚Äù or ‚Äúconcealment‚Äù where there is none.

Romualdez‚Äôs explanation aligns with legal reality: the property was bought in 1988, long before he entered politics, and has been openly declared in his SALN for years.

(Note: Under the Duterte administration, Ombudsman Samuel Martires required notarized consent before anyone could access SALNs, making public viewing harder.)

If he had declared this property in earlier SALNs, where‚Äôs the concealment?

Rappler even mentions that the receiving corporation, AMMY Inc., has Filipinos connected to Romualdez ‚Äî which proves nothing. So ano naman ngayon?

It‚Äôs perfectly normal to include trusted associates or family members in a corporation that manages one‚Äôs property. 

In fact, it‚Äôs wiser if the owner controls the corporation. Many private owners do that: they form their own companies to hold and protect their assets.

Common practice din naman yan sa Pilipinas, di ba? 

See? May malice din mag-insinuate ang Rappler. Their entire ‚Äúcontroversy‚Äù is built on optics, not facts.

‚ÄúPerception is real‚Äù talaga in politics, no? The reality is often ignored.

Bawal na ba maging intellectually honest even sa investigative reporting?

It seems what matters is that a topic looks scandalous enough to make readers click and subscribe‚Ä¶ only to realize later, ‚ÄúSo what‚Äôs this article trying to prove? Puro hanash at insinuations lang, nasaan ang actual scandal dito?‚Äù üòÇ

Controversial headlines = more clicks = more subscriptions = more ka-ching! üí∏

Actually, depende rin sa nagbabasa. Kung jejemon ka na allergic sa comprehension (or di mo talaga naiintindihan because of lack of experience, which is fair), corruption agad ang basa mo. üòÇ

FISHING EXPEDITION‚Äô 

Tinawag ni Palace Press Officer Usec. Claire Castro na ‚Äúfishing expedition‚Äù lamang para siraan si First Lady Liza Marcos ang alegasyong sangkot siya sa maanomalyang flood control projects.  

Ito ay matapos magsumite ng letter of sentiment sa Independent Commission for Infrastructure (ICI) ang isang private citizen na nagngangalang John Santander para paimbestigahan ang koneksyon ng First Lady kay Special Envoy to China for Trade, Investments and Tourism Maynard Ngu kaugnay ng flood control anomalies.  

Giit ni Castro, hearsay evidence ito na hindi na dapat pagtuunan ng pansin.

Alam namin ang modus ng pag sunog ‚Äì nuon yung City Hall or Hall of Justice nasusunog para yung mga titulo ng lupa mawala or magulo. Ngayon naman sinunog nyo ang DPWH.

Mistulang nagtugma ang magkahiwalay na pahayag nina Ombudsman Jesus Crispin Remulla at former senator Antonio ‚ÄòSonny‚Äô Trillanes IV tungkol sa sinasabing kaugnayan ng mag-asawang contractor na Curlee at Sarah Discaya kay Senator Bong Go.

Ito ay matapos ibunyag ni Trillanes sa interview sa kanya ng ONE News nitong Oktubre 21 na sinabi umano sa kanya ni Pasig City Mayor Vico Sotto na si Go ang ‚Äúnasa likod‚Äù ng pag-asenso ng mag-asawang Discaya.

Nagsalita si Trillanes ilang oras matapos siyang maghain ng kasong plunder sa Office of the Ombudsman laban kay Go, sa ama at kapatid nito, at kay dating pangulong Rodrigo Duterte dahil sa pagkakakopo umano ng P7-billion infrastructure projects contracts mula sa gobyerno simula 2007 hanggang 2023.

Nauna rito, ibinunyag ni Remulla sa media na mistulang may mga personalidad umanong pinoprotektahan ang mag-asawang Discaya kaya tumanggi na itong makipagtulungan sa imbestigasyon sa flood control scam‚Äîat partikular na binanggit ang pangalan ni Go.

Matatandaang sa Senate hearing noong Setyembre 1, inamin mismo ni Sarah Discaya na nagkaroon ng joint venture noong 2017 ang isa sa mga kumpanya nila, ang St. Gerrard Construction, sa CLTG Builders ni Deciderio Go, ama ng senador.

COURTESY: DPWH

A third alarm fire broke out at the Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) office in Quezon City on Tuesday, engulfing the Bureau of Research and Standards (BRS) before it was declared under control after more than 30 minutes. 

The DPWH-BRS serves as the agency's technical arm responsible for formulating and enforcing engineering standards, accrediting materials engineers and testing laboratories, and conducting research and quality assurance tests on construction materials such as asphalt, cement, and concrete to ensure the durability and safety of public infrastructure projects.

Investigators are still determining the cause of the fire.

CAYETANO ON DPWH MESS: 'I DON'T WANT A REVOLUTION, I WANT A REVIVAL'

Senate Minority Leader Alan Peter Cayetano on Monday urged the Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) to lead not only in building infrastructure but also in restoring integrity and accountability within the agency, starting with a crackdown on ghost projects.

"I don't want a revolution, I want a revival," Cayetano said during the DPWH's budget briefing on October 20. "Many revolutions did not bring the reforms that were promised. Do you agree with me na dapat yung low-lying fruit, 'yung obvious na obvious, iyon 'yung [dapat] unahin?"

Cayetano called ghost projects the "clearest and most blatant form of corruption," stressing that these should be the department's top priority in its anti-corruption drive.

"Ang definition ng 'ghost [projects],' nag-allocate ng pera [at] binayaran, pero wala talagang project. It's easier to focus on that kasi walang mapapaliwanag 'yung guilty" he said.

He said the DPWH's mission in nation-building must be twofold‚Äîto build infrastructure and to clean up corruption within its ranks‚Äîadding that reforms should go beyond prevention.

"The biblical principle is prevent evil, do good, pero if you're going to be spiritual, may isa pa: align with what God wants. If you apply it to civil government, it's not enough that we prevent corruption and do good. We have to align the priorities sa kung ano ang priority ng administration," Cayetano said.

DPWH Secretary Vince Dizon agreed, disclosing that more than 400 suspected ghost projects have been identified by a validation team and assuring that those involved will be held accountable.

Cayetano urged swift action, saying the department should use existing documents as evidence and refer cases to the Independent Commission for Infrastructure (ICI) or the Ombudsman if needed.

He also proposed requiring district engineers and local officials to take and submit photos of project sites to help verify progress and prevent ghost projects.

"Reform doesn't come from tearing things down but from rebuilding them right," Cayetano said. "That's the kind of revival our country needs."

Summary of bombshells dropped by Congressman Leandro Leviste in his interview:

üí£ 1. At least one member of Secretary Vince Dizon‚Äôs team [in the DPWH] is a contractor.

üí£ 2. One USec. met with three contractors and [yung Usec ang] nang hihingi‚Ä¶ and Vince Dizon is aware of it.‚Äù

üí£ 3. The DPWH has two categories in the budget called ‚Äúallocables‚Äù and ‚Äúnon-allocables‚Äù.

Allocables are like pork barrel budget allocations that a Congressman can touch and revise.

Non-allocables are infra projects under the DPWH that a Congressman cannot touch because allegedly such budget has been ‚Äúbought‚Äù or ‚Äúreserved‚Äù by a contractor in connivance with the DPWH (usually an Undersecretary).

üí£ 4. Contractors approached him after the 2025 Elections to offer 25% kickback for projects. He was only able to entrap the District Engineer because may papel, may resibo, may computation, and may perang dala.

üí£ 5. One Congressman-Contractor based in Batangas approached him and offered him 25% kickback as well.

Nanawagan si Education Secretary Sonny Angara ng mga reporma sa sistema ng pagpapatayo ng mga silid-aralan para matugunan ang matagal nang classroom shortage.

Ito ay kasunod ng ulat sa mabagal na paggawa ng Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH), kung saan 22 pa lang sa 1,700 target na silid-aralan ang natapos ngayong taon.

Bukod sa mga LGU, tinitingnan na rin ni Sec. Angara ang posibilidad na pangunahan ng DepEd ang konstruksyon, kasama ang public-private partnerships (PPP), at mga katuwang tulad ng Engineering Brigades ng Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP).

Sa ngayon, may 146,708 backlogs sa mga silid-aralan sa buong bansa, habang 22,092 classrooms na ang natapos ng DepEd at DPWH mula Hulyo 2022 hanggang Hulyo 2025.

Grupong UPACC o United Pilipino Against Crime and Corruption, naghain ng reklamong plunder sa Ombudsman laban kina Tarlac 3rd District Rep. Noel Rivera, sa asawa niyang si Concepcion, Tarlac Vice Mayor Evelyn Rivera at kay DPWH Tarlac 1st District Engineer Neil Farala. 

Para daw ito sa mahigit P600 milyon na halaga ng infrastructure projects na napunta sa Tarlac 3G Construction kung saan umano CEO, general manager at presidente si Cong. Rivera habang incorporator at treasurer naman si Vice Mayor Rivera.

Pinahaharap din sila sa mga reklamomg grave misconduct, serious dishonesty, and violation of the government procurement reform act.

Ayon kay UPACC Chairperson Pyra Lucas, mahigit 13 kontrata raw ng Tarlac 3G Construction sa DPWH ang pirmado pa ni Rivera kahit nakapuwesto na siya bilang kongresista.

Malinaw raw na conflict of interest ito at hindi maitatangging naimpluwensiyahan nila ang mga kontrata sa 1st, 2nd at 3rd district ng Tarlac.

Nai-report na raw ito ng UPACC sa ICI at maging sa DPWH noong panahon ni dating Sec. Manuel Bonoan. 

Bukas ang GMA Integrated News sa pagtanggap ng pahayag ni Cong. Rivera at ng iba pang sangkot sa inihaing reklamo. | via Saleema Refran/GMA Integrated News

Sa isang official statement nitong Lunes, Oktubre 21, nagpahayag ng pagkadismaya ang Department of Education (DepEd) sa ulat na 22 sa 1,700 target classrooms pa lamang ang natapos ng Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) ngayong taon.

Ayon sa DepEd, ilan sa mga dahilan ng mabagal na pagpapatayo ng mga silid-aralan ay ang sobrang daming proyekto ng DPWH, huling pagsusumite ng validation at costing, at mga pagbabago sa pamunuan ng kagawaran.

Dahil dito, tiniyak ng ahensya na isulong ang mas flexible na sistema sa 2026 budget, para hindi na lang DPWH ang makapagpatupad ng mga proyekto, kundi maging ang DepEd mismo.

A progressive group on Wednesday filed complaints before the Office of the Ombudsman against Tarlac 3rd District Rep. Noel Rivera, his wife, Concepcion Vice Mayor Evelyn Rivera, and DPWH Tarlac 1st District Engineer Neil Farala over alleged collusion to secure government contracts worth P600 million for a company owned by the couple.

The complainant, Pyra Lucas, founder of United Pilipino Against Crime and Corruption (UPACC), said Rep. Rivera signed around 30 government contracts for his own company, 3G Construction & Development Corporation, since 2018.

Lucas said the lawmaker allegedly failed to divest from the company which led to a conflict of interest. She also urged the Ombudsman to investigate the couple‚Äôs alleged mansions, landholdings, and resort properties. 

The respondents face allegations of violating the Anti-Plunder Act, the Anti-Graft and Corrupt Practices Act, unexplained wealth provisions, and the Government Procurement Act. They are also accused of abuse of authority, conduct prejudicial to the best interest of the service, grave misconduct, and serious dishonesty. | via @173014809800962

ROMUALDEZ INILIPAT ANG ‚Ç±130-M US PROPERTY KAPALIT NG ‚Ç±58 ($1)

Sa isang "kahina-hinala" at maaaring ituring umano na "fraudulent conveyance" ayon sa ilang US lawyers, lumabas na inilipat ni Ex-Speaker Martin Romualdez ang kanyang P130.5 milyong ($2.24M) ari-arian sa Dover, Massachusetts sa kumpanyang konektado umano sa kanyang fraternity brod sa halagang ‚Ç±58 o $1 lamang.

Ang property ay pag-aari ni Romualdez mula pa noong 1988, nang bilhin niya ito sa halagang $650,000. Sa ngayon, tinatayang nasa $2.24 milyon na ang halaga ng estate na may lawak na 2.5 ektarya at matatagpuan sa pinakamayamang bayan sa Massachusetts.

Ayon sa investigative report ng Rappler, nailipat ang pagmamay-ari noong Hulyo 29, 2025 sa kumpanyang AMMY INC., ilang buwan bago pumutok ang mga isyu ng korapsyon sa flood control projects at bago ang SONA ng Pangulo.

Ipinaliwanag ni Romualdez sa kanyang pahayag noong Oktubre 21 na:
‚ÄúArrangement was made solely for property management purposes.‚Äù
(‚ÄúGinawa ang kasunduan para lamang sa layunin ng pamamahala ng ari-arian.‚Äù)

Dagdag pa niya, walang pagtatago o paglabag sa batas sa naturang transaksyon at matagal na raw nakadeklara sa kanyang Statement of Assets, Liabilities, and Net Worth (SALN) ang nasabing property.

Bagama‚Äôt legal ang paggamit ng quitclaim deed sa ganitong transaksyon, itinuring ng ilang US-based lawyers na ‚Äúfraudulent conveyance‚Äù kung ito‚Äôy ginamit para itago ang mga ari-arian sa mga posibleng nagsasampa ng kaso o naghahabol ng utang.

Lumabas din sa dokumento na ang AMMY INC. ay pinamumunuan ni Andrew Casi√±o, isang direktor umano ng Benguet Corporation ‚Äî kumpanyang pagmamay-ari ng pamilya Romualdez ‚Äî at frat brother umano ni Martin sa Upsilon Sigma Phi.

On Rappler's "Bombshell" Report

For anyone desperate to find fault in Congressman Martin Romualdez, it is easy to overlook details of facts and hone in on big bold declarations that fit personal biases against him.

The reporting bias here is evident as it skewers disconnected issues together to sway reader sentiments to grill the former Speaker. But for anyone with a taste for deep reading and analysis, they will see that this propaganda dish does the opposite. 

What this report has effectively presented is that Martin Romualdez purchased the Massachusetts property way back in 1988. He was 25 years old and was 19 years away from entering politics. 

This means that this property is in no way, shape or form a part of the discussion of the national budget and its subsequent corruption. He had no access to government funds at the time of its purchase. To say otherwise or to even insinuate its association to current issues is intellectually dishonest and misleading.

Next. It is not uncommon or unheard of in private portfolio management or corporate restructuring to sell properties for $1. This has been practiced by many entities or companies worldwide. (See attached screenshot)
 
Another. The execution of the property transfer predates even a whisper of the DPWH anomalies or the formation of the ICI. In fact, Martin Romualdez was not even re-elected as Speaker at the time. 

This means that the report attaching this matter to the current anti-corruption hearings is clearly just rage baiting its readers. The actual journalism value is quite low.

Where is Rappler's vaunted journalistic practices when it researched, wrote, edited and published this report? The issues meant to draw a picture of malice draws ire instead. This is a hodgepodge series of events without cohesion or congruence.

Mere insinuations and innuendos are and will never be facts. If the intention is to destroy Martin Romualdez, media needs to do better, much, much better than this.

üö®Courtesy Call or Subtle Interference?üö®

When a foreign official from the U.S. Embassy suddenly makes a ‚Äúcourtesy call‚Äù to the ICI the very body currently investigating the multi-trillion peso Ghost Project flood control scandal, the timing alone raises eyebrows.

This is not just a routine diplomatic visit. Courtesy calls are usually made to heads of state, foreign ministers, or economic agencies,  not to an independent investigative commission. Even high-ranking Filipino officials don‚Äôt normally ‚Äúdrop by‚Äù to greet investigators looking into domestic corruption cases. So why the unusual visit?

In the language of diplomacy, context matters. When an embassy official appears at a sensitive investigation hub, it sends signals, intentional or not, about interest, influence, or involvement. And in a time when billions in infrastructure funds are under scrutiny, this move feels less like ‚Äúdiplomacy‚Äù and more like a shadow hovering over accountability.

The ICI‚Äôs work is about truth, transparency, and sovereignty. Allowing any foreign presence, no matter how ‚Äúfriendly‚Äù, during an active probe risks perception of undue influence. Because if even our own senators or auditors are cautious about making calls that could taint the process, then surely, a foreign envoy should know better.

In moments like this, one must ask:
üëâ Is it really a ‚Äúcourtesy call‚Äù?
Or is it a ‚Äúcurious call‚Äù, a quiet attempt to feel the pulse of a scandal too sensitive for comfort?

The Philippines has fought too long to keep its institutions independent. The least our so-called allies can do is respect the sanctity of our investigations.

Why Did The Original Constitution Of The United States Specify That Senators To Be Elected By State Legislatures?
Why is it referred to as the Upper Chamber? Anybody Know?

It's because the original framework set the House of Representatives to be the representatives of the people in Washington with just 2 year terms so they could be voted out sooner if their performance was insufficient.

The Senate was originally intended to be representation in Washington of the individual states interests, think 10th amendment, and selecting them through the state legislatures rather than popular vote was a means to assure they were of a more sophisticated, better educated better informed pool of candidates dedicated to representing their state's interests in Congress, giving them 6 year terms because of this reasoning.

It was a perfect balance between federal, state and citizen representation in the federal government.

But the 17th amendment altered this well conceived balance between the Federal government, the people and the state's abilities to restrain federal authority and overreach. Basically, it neutered the states influence in Washington DC.

There are several reasons given for this change. One deals with perceived malfeasance or corruption in the Senate, but look what we have now by ratifying the 17th. malfeasance and corruption in the Senate.
The other reason I posit here is that the 17th amendment was ratified the same year as the 16th, just prior to WW1. That's right, a new tax on the people. The income tax. A new tax to fund a war they knew was coming just a year later. Every war since has been funded by the income tax. Every damned one of them, just or unjust, all of them. So why was the 17th ratified? Was it to neuter the states ability to keep us out of that war? I think so.

Our Constitution has been butchered by amendments since it's inception. We need to get back to it's original design. Repeal the 16th and 17th amendments.

Transcription of his dramatic monologue: 

He wants the truth. But when the truth begins to surface, he's the first to grab a mop, not to clean, but to erase his footprints. 

Here stands the man who used people to manipulate the budget, endorsed the projects, and now claims to be the one demanding accountability. 

Ang linis ng dating, pero ang baho ang sistema. 

After snubbing the first meeting last October 1, Martin Romualdez finally appeared before the Independent Commission for Infrastructure. 

But this time, the man who once trotted across the halls of Congress, like he owned every wall and surface, seemed... smaller. 

The confidence that once filled the room had melted, the aura of arrogance gone, replaced by a forced composure and the uneasy calm of someone who knows that this time, the walls are watching back. 

And now, as the flood rises, he points his finger not at himself, but at the very people who stood beside him when he held the gable. 

Suddenly, it's Zaldy Co. Suddenly, it's Chiz  Escudero. Ganyan ang husay ng narrative control, the art of washing hands while putting others drown. 

Sa dulo, ang malilinis na pangalan ang laging nalununod sa putik ng pulitika. 

He speaks of transparency, yet every document leads back to the desks he once ruled. 

He talks of accountability, yet his defense is to scatter the blame like sandbags around a sinking ship. 

I want the truth, he says. Then let the truth come, even if it washes over those who once carried his cause. 

Because, sometimes, the dirtiest hands are the ones holding the broom.

9 months ago, PBBM described the 2025 GAA as sub-optimal, noting that it no longer reflects the priorities set in the National Expenditure Program. Several key programs were underfunded or left out entirely, resulting in a budget that Malaca√±ang considers less efficient than originally planned. 

For infrastructure projects,  when a project is billed as completed and paid for but appears not to have been done (ghost project / falsified records), he regards that as economic sabotage because of large loss of public funds.

Critics remain critical of the administration's actions to address the issue, but the government has since taken steps to remedy and correct the systemic problems.

PBBM has shown seriousness in uncovering the truth and holding erring officials accountable. In just three months, his administration has taken visible steps to identify irregularities and enforce accountability across key agencies.

ACTIONS TAKEN BY PBBM TO MITIGATE CORRUPTION

‚úÖPublicly disclosed that 15 contractors had allegedly secured 20% of all flood control contracts (P100B out of  P545B) between July 2022 and May 2025. 
‚úÖThe contractors were identified and named by PBBM in August 2025.  20% of the entire 545B budget went to just 15 contractors
‚úÖOrdered a deep audit/verification of the flood control projects by DPWH and other agencies
‚úÖThe audit flagged that 6,021 out of 9,855 flood control projects lacked specific detail on the type of structure built/rehabbed, covering over P350B. ‚úÖPBBM launched a public complaints portal,
to allow citizen feedback on flood control projects. The complaints website allows citizens to submit feedback, photos, and videos of flood control or infrastructure projects. Encouraging LGUs and civil society to monitor local infrastructure projects.
‚úÖCreation of a special independent fact-finding commission ICI to investigate infrastructure anomalies, including those in DPWH flood control projects. The ICI is tasked with reviewing past projects, issuing subpoenas, referring matters for prosecution etc.
‚úÖImplemented lifestyle checks and asset reviews on government personnel tied to irregular projects.
‚úÖOrdered COA and the Ombudsman to fast-track investigations and coordinate findings for possible prosecution.
‚úÖThe appointment of a new DPWH Secretary Vince‚ÄØDizon, and ordering courtesy resignations from officials at multiple levels to rebuild accountability.  Emphasis that "even those close to me will not be spared from accountability".
‚úÖVetoing and cutting budget items deemed unaligned / introducing transparency steps: Although not specific to DPWH only, the administration signaled that future budgets must align with the national plan (NEP) and pursuing wasted/unprogrammed items will be removed.  Example: Marcos described the budget as "sub-optimal" and committed to pursuing savings and realignment.
‚úÖ BSP on its new circular limits cash payouts/withdrawals from banks and other supervised institutions to ‚Ç±500,000 (or equivalent in foreign currency) per banking day, whether in a single transaction or a series of transactions.
‚úÖNew jail facility for corruption suspects
‚úÖBureau of Immigration issued Look Out bulletin orders of individuals involved in ghost flood control projects.
‚úÖHenry‚ÄØAlcantara, Brice Hernandez, and Jaypee Mendoza were dismissed due to involvement or implicated in the flood control projects.
‚úÖPreventive suspension of 16 employees of DPWH Bulacan 1st District Engineering Office
‚úÖAll DPWH officials (Undersecretaries, Assistant Secretaries, Division Heads, District Engineers) were ordered to submit resignations nationwide as part of the agency's clean sweep.
‚úÖDirected asset freeze and recovery efforts and referrals for prosecution.  The Palace and investigating bodies directed agencies to trace and recover public funds; COA and ICI findings are being referred to the Ombudsman, DOJ or Sandiganbayan as appropriate.
‚úÖProject legitimacy and transparency: Requiring LGU acceptance of projects, stopping projects that have no trace, and improving monitoring. The goal is fewer projects that are paid but not built (ghost projects) and more value for money.

While several officials have been suspended, dismissed, or forced to resign, no convictions have been made. The Palace maintains that prosecutions must be based on solid evidence to ensure cases do not collapse later for lack of proof. 

Until some groups are convicted, our role is to stay vigilant, informed, and engaged. We must demand transparency in how investigations are handled, verify information before sharing it, and support reforms that strengthen oversight and accountability. Real change requires public pressure that is rooted in facts, not noise or speculation, so that anti corruption efforts lead to lasting institutional reform, not just temporary headlines.

The Blockchain Council of the Philippines (BCP) is proposing a pilot project to put a portion of the Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) budget on a blockchain ledger. The initiative aims to enhance transparency, accountability, and traceability in infrastructure spending, allowing real-time public access to fund movements.

According to the council, blockchain‚Äôs immutable recordkeeping can help prevent budget misuse and corruption, while enabling citizens to track how projects are implemented. If successful, the pilot could pave the way for nationwide blockchain-based fiscal systems, modernizing how public funds are managed and audited in the Philippines.

Uminit ang ulo ni Senador Rodante Marcoleta sa budget hearing ng Department of Justice (DOJ) matapos nitong sitahin ang ahensya sa umano‚Äôy dagdag na kondisyon bago maisama sa Witness Protection Program (WPP) ang mga Discaya, na pangunahing testigo sa isyu ng flood control corruption.

Mariin niyang kinuwestiyon kung bakit kailangang isauli muna ng mga Discaya ang umano‚Äôy kinita nila bago sila bigyan ng proteksyon ng estado.

‚ÄúPaano ninyo ipoproseso ang aplikasyon kung kayo mismo ang gumagawa ng rekisitong wala naman sa batas?‚Äù

Dagdag pa ni Sen. Marcoleta, tila pinipili lamang ng DOJ ang mga nais nilang iproseso at protektahan.

‚ÄúSo pinipili n‚Äôyo ‚Äòyung gusto n‚Äôyong i-process?
Sila (Discaya) lamang ang nakapag-identify, initially ng 17 congressmen? At doon sa kanilang mga testimony, lumalabas na rin ang pangalan ni Zaldy Co‚Ä¶ at Martin Romualdez. Ngayon kung ayaw n‚Äôyong bigyan sila ng protection under that law, kaya siguro umayaw na sila sa ICI.‚Äù

Giit ng senador, hindi niya dinidepensahan ang mga Discaya, kundi nais lang niyang matukoy kung sino ang utak ng anomalya.

‚ÄúHindi ko dinidepensahan ang mga taong ‚Äòyon. Gusto ko lang ‚Äòyon para ma-identify ang mastermind.‚Äù

Binanatan din niya ang DOJ sa umano‚Äôy kawalan ng direksyon sa pagpili ng testigo:

‚ÄúKung gusto n‚Äôyong ang ma-identify ay puro butete at sapsap, bahala na kayo sa buhay n‚Äôyo!‚Äù

Ayon kay Senador Marcoleta, kung ganito raw ang patakaran ng DOJ, hindi kailanman matutukoy ang mga tunay na nasa likod ng multi-billion flood control scandal.

Corruption in the DPWH has been deeply rooted for decades. Even Duterte exposed it back in 2019 but failed to take real action. Now, under PBBM, we finally have a leader with the political will to confront it head-on: he created the ICI, launched Sumbong sa Pangulo and named the top contractors involved.

Yet some people are impatient and now blame him for the very corruption he‚Äôs fighting. If we replace the only president brave enough to clean up the system with another Duterte who ignored it, what future are we really choosing for our country?

Why not support PBBM to finish what he started? This magnitude of corruption takes time to dismantle. We must follow due process and the rule of law so the cases won‚Äôt just be for show but to ensure that justice is served and the people can finally recover what was stolen from them.

The Blockchain Council of the Philippines (BCP) is proposing a pilot project to host portions of the Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) budget on a blockchain ledger. The initiative seeks to test how decentralized records can improve transparency, audit trails, and public accountability in infrastructure fund management.

According to BCP, the system would make budget tracking and contract monitoring tamper-proof, allowing citizens and oversight agencies to verify transactions in real time. The group said it hopes the pilot will serve as a proof of concept for broader blockchain adoption across government procurement and spending programs.

@9881941870936 With all due respect to Senator Orji Uzor Kalu, the idea that the Senate and House of Representatives alone should determine the tenure of political office holders is fundamentally flawed. These lawmakers are not rulers; they are representatives of the people. Therefore, any decision that directly shapes the destiny of our democracy must be subjected to the consent of the very people they represent. A constitution is not the property of the National Assembly, it is the collective covenant of the Nigerian people. Even the current constitution is a fraud.

A review of the 1999 Constitution, especially on tenure and governance structure, must not be an elite-driven exercise. It must be people-driven, transparent, and rooted in the will of Nigerians. To decide otherwise is to perpetuate the arrogance of a political class that sees governance as a private business, not a public trust.

Now, to the issue itself: a five-year single term would serve Nigeria better. It would reduce the obsession with re-election, compel leaders to focus on governance, and minimize the waste of national resources that comes with endless campaigns. But tenure alone won‚Äôt save us unless we fix the culture of impunity that has rotted our system.

That‚Äôs why no public office holder should enjoy immunity. No one should be above the law, not the president, not governors, not legislators. If any public officer violates the constitution or betrays public trust, citizens must have the right and mechanism to remove them through due process. Accountability should be non-negotiable.

Equally, no public official should be funded to live in luxury at public expense. No government cars, no bloated convoys. Let those who claim to serve buy their cars and rent their houses  with their own money, as ordinary Nigerians do. Leadership is about sacrifice, not privilege.

Furthermore, the Senate and House of Representatives should be part-time roles. Lawmaking should not be a full-time meal ticket. Our legislators should have real jobs, real businesses, real lives. They should only converge when national duty calls, and be paid sitting allowances, not fat salaries for sleeping through plenary sessions. That‚Äôs how you breed public servants, not professional politicians.

And let‚Äôs be honest; people like Senator Orji Uzor Kalu represent the rot we are trying to clean. If Nigeria were a serious country, men with credible records of looting state funds would not be pontificating about constitutional reform, they will be serving their sentences. We can not build a nation on deceit, selective justice, and hypocrisy. For too long we‚Äôve pretended that corruption is leadership, and that impunity is wisdom. The decay we see today is the natural harvest of those lies.

If we truly want a new Nigeria, we must start with truth. And the truth is simple: you can not reform a system with the same people who broke it.

The Land Transportation Office (LTO) has identified three buildings inside its compound worth nearly ‚Ç±2 billion that were built by Sunwest Construction Corporation, the company owned by resigned Ako Bicol Party-list Rep. Zaldy Co. 

LTO Assistant Secretary Markus Lacanilao said the three buildings include an IT Hub Training Seminar Building with no IT equipment, a Road Safety Seminar Building, and a Central Command Center. 

Records show that the contract between the LTO and a joint venture of Sunwest Construction Corporation and another firm was signed on February 26, 2021. 

The Commission on Audit has issued findings identifying the buildings as unutilized or built but not in use, Lacanilao said.

Based on LTO documents, the projects were fully paid as of December 2024 and were accepted by former Assistant Secretary Vigor Mendoza. 

Lacanilao said he has forwarded the documents to the Independent Commission for Infrastructure (ICI).

(Video via Val Gonzales, DZRH News)

DS Ortega welcomes MBC call for due process for all, including former Speaker Romualdez in flood control probe

DEPUTY Speaker Paolo Ortega V of La Union on Tuesday welcomed the statement of Makati Business Club (MBC) Executive Director Apa Ongpin, saying he echoed the public‚Äôs call for fairness and due process in the ongoing probe on alleged flood control anomalies. 

Ortega lauded Ongpin‚Äôs remarks, saying they reflect the same principles of transparency and accountability being advanced by the Independent Commission for Infrastructure (ICI) and by former Speaker Romualdez himself, who has consistently cooperated with the inquiry.

Deputy Speaker Ortega said, ‚ÄòWe welcome Mr. Ongpin‚Äôs statement as a reminder that justice must never be selective. The process must be based on facts, not political color or pressure,‚Äù Ortega said. 

Ongpin said that like anyone else, former Speaker Romualdez deserves due process and a fair, independent investigation.

He also stressed that investigators must act free from political interference and ensure all those accused are given the chance to defend themselves properly.

Ortega emphasized that former Speaker Romualdez had already demonstrated integrity by stepping down as Speaker last month to ensure ‚Äúfull accountability and transparency‚Äù amid the ongoing investigation.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve seen the former Speaker face these issues squarely. He has cooperated with investigators and remains committed to the truth. That‚Äôs the kind of leadership the public deserves to see,‚Äù Ortega added.

The La Union House leader reiterated that due process is the cornerstone of justice, saying the government‚Äôs credibility in its anti-corruption drive depends on impartial investigations.

‚ÄúLet‚Äôs allow the truth to come out through proper process,‚Äù Ortega said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs how we uphold the rule of law and protect the integrity of our institutions.‚Äù

Leviste Admits He Made a Mistake in Tagging a DPWH Official

Batangas Representative Leandro Leviste admitted he made a mistake in naming one of the Department of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) undersecretaries he accused of meeting with contractors.

The mix-up began on October 16, 2025, when DPWH Secretary Vince Dizon publicly challenged Leviste to name the officials he claimed were connected to contractors. Leviste responded by naming Undersecretary Arrey Perez as one of them. Hours later, however, after Perez resigned from his post, Leviste clarified that he had identified the wrong person.

He said Perez was not the official in the photograph allegedly showing a DPWH undersecretary meeting with three contractors at a restaurant. According to Leviste, the man in the photo was another undersecretary‚Äîsomeone he still refused to name.

Yet even as he admitted the error, Leviste‚Äôs statements only added to the confusion. He maintained that Perez still had ‚Äúlinks‚Äù to contractors, insisting that most DPWH appointees were being approached by them. He explained that while some officials might refuse to meet with contractors, others did not.

Perez, who had only been in office for 18 days, resigned the same day Leviste made the clarification. In his resignation letter, he said the accusations had turned public service into a political game and that he did not want to become a source of distraction for the department.

The situation left Leviste‚Äôs allegations muddled. He had initially singled out Perez as one example of officials involved with contractors, only to retract the specific restaurant‚Äêmeeting claim while keeping his broader accusation about contractor ties. This contradictory stance blurred his message‚Äîwas he targeting individuals or calling out the entire system?

Leviste maintained that his goal was reform: to reduce DPWH project costs and eliminate kickbacks. But his premature naming of Perez, followed by a partial retraction, overshadowed that message and raised doubts about the reliability of his claims.

Prioritise people's welfare, ensure transparency, Speaker Abbas charges SSDC

The Speaker of the House of Representatives Rt. Hon. Abbas Tajudeen, Ph.D., GCON, has urged the South South Development Commission (SSDC) to live up to its mandate by bringing development to the people especially at the grassroots.

Speaker Abbas particularly urged the SSDC to address the socio-economic challenges for which the Commission was created.

The Speaker gave the charge on Thursday when the board and management of the SSDC visited him in Abuja.

‚ÄúThis is an opportunity to set a legacy for future generations. Serve with integrity, coordination, and vision,‚Äù Speaker Abbas admonished the SSDC leadership, just as he urged the board and the management to prioritise the best interest of the South-South people.

While urging them to work closely with state governors to improve synergy, the Speaker warned against corruption, including duplication of projects, and mandates. He also called for the building of a strong institutional foundation for the future.

Speaker Abbas also advised the SSDC to conduct proper needs assessments before interventions.

The Speaker expressed the commitment of the House to giving full support to the SSDC to deliver sustainable development and stability to the South-South geopolitical zone.

The Managing Director, SSDC, Mrs Usoro Offiong Akpabio, who led the delegation, earlier said the Commission is ready to commence full operations.

Mrs Akpabio also noted that the mandate of the SSDC is in line with President Bola Ahmed Tinubu‚Äôs Renewed Hope Agenda.

The SSDC boss also highlighted some of the Commission‚Äôs programmes and projects which cover infrastructure renewal, human capital development, environmental protection, as well as youth and women empowerment.

Mrs Akpabio pledged accountability and transparency under her watch as MD of the SSDC.
